div.p: A POSTHUME of RICHARD BROME, An Ingenious Servant, and Imitator of his Maſter, that famouſly Renowned Poet Ben. Johnſon.

p.hi:
Aut prodeſſe ſolent, aut delectare Poetae.
Dramatis Perſonae.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Andrew Crook, and are to be ſold at the Green Dragon in St. Pauls Church-yard: And Henry Broom at the Gun in Ivy-lane. 1658.

div.head: Upon AGLAƲRA printed in Folio.
div.l: Br this large Margent did the Poet mean
To have a Comment writ upon his Scene?
Or is it that the Ladies, who ne're look
On any but a Poeme or Play-book,
May, in each page, have ſpace to ſcribble down
When ſuch a Lord, or Faſhion comes to Town.
As Swaines in Almanacks account do keep,
When their Cow calv'd, and when they bought their ſheep?
Ink is the life of Paper: 'tis meet then,
That this which ſcap'd the Preſs ſhould feel the Pen.
A Room with one ſide furniſh'd, or a face
Painted half-way, is but a faire diſgrace.
This great voluminous Pamphlet may be ſaid
To be like one that hath more haire then head;
More excrement then body. Trees, which ſprout
With broadest leaves, have ſtill the ſmallest fruit.
When I ſaw ſo much white, I did begin
To think Aglaura either did lie in,
Or elſe took Pennance. Never did I ſee
(unleſſe in Bills daſht In the Chancerie).
So little in ſo much; as if the feet
Of Poetry, like Law, were ſold by th'ſheet.
If this new faſhion ſhould but laſt one yeare,
Poets, as Clerks, would make our paper dear.
Doth not the Artiſt erre, and blast his fame
That ſets out pictures leſſer then the frame?
Was ever Chamberlaine ſo mad, to dare
To lodge a childe in the great Bed at Ware?
Aglaura wo●ld pleaſe better, did ſhe lie
I'th' narrow bounds of an Epitomie.
Pieces that are weav'd of the finest twiſt,
(As Silk and Pluſh) have ſtill more ſtuffe then liſt.
She, that in Perſian habit made great brags,
Degenerates in this exceſſe of rags;
Who, by her Giant-bulk this only gaines,
Perchance in Libraries to hang in chaines.
Tis not in Book, as Cloth; we never ſay
Make London-meaſure, when we buy a Play:
But rather have them pair'd: Thoſe leaves be faire
To the judicious, which more ſpotted are.
Give me the ſociable Pocket-books.
Theſe empty Folio's only pleaſe the Cooks.

div.head: A SONG.
div.l: A Way with all grief and give us more ſack.
'Tis that which we love, let love have no lack.
Nor ſorrow, nor care can croſſe our delights,
Nor witches, nor goblins, nor Buttery ſprights,
Tho' the candles burne dimme while we can do thus,
We'll ſcorn to flie them: but we'll make them flie us.
Old Sack, and old Songs, and a merry old crew
Will fright away Sprights, when the ground looks blew.

div.head: A PROLOGUE.
div.l: HE that could never boaſt, nor ſeek the way,
To prepare friends to magnifie his Play,
Nor raile at's Auditory for unjuſt,
If they not lik't it nor was ſo miſtrust.
Ful ever in himſelf, that he beſought
Preapprobation though they lik't it not.
Nor ever had the luck to have his name
Clap't up above this merit. Nor the ſhame
To be cried down below it. He this night
Your faire and free Attention does invite.
Only he prays no prejudice be brought
By any that before-hand wiſh it nought.
And that ye all be pleaſ'd to heare and ſee,
With Candor ſuiting his Integritie.
That for the Writer. Something we muſt ſay,
Now in defence of us, and of the Play
We ſhall preſent no Scandal or Abuſe,
To vertue or to honour. Nor traduce
Perſon of worth. Nor point at the diſgrace
Of any one reſiding in the Place,
On which our Scene is laid, nor any Action ſhew,
Of thing has there been done, for ought we know.
Though it be probable that ſuch have been.
But if ſome vicious perſons be brought in.
As no new Buildings, nor the ſtrongeſt hold
Can keep ou● Rats and Vermine bad and bold.
Let not the ſight of ſuch be ill endur'd;
All ſores are ſeen and ſearch't before th' are cur'd.
As Ruffian, Bawd, and the licentious crew,
Too apt to peſter Scituations new.

div.head: Another Prologue.
div.l: 'Tis not amiſſe ere we begin our Play,
T' intreat you, that you take the ſame ſurveigh
Into your fancie, as our Poet took,
Of Covent-Garden, when he wrote his Book.
Some ten years ſince, when it was grown with weeds.
Not ſet, as now it is, with Noble Seeds.
Which make the Garden glorious. And much
Our Poet craves and hopes you will not grutch
It him, that ſince ſo happily his Pen
Foretold its faire emprovement, and that men
Of worth and honour ſhould renown the place.
The Play may ſtill retain its former grace.

div.head: To my LORD of Newcaſtle, on his PLAY called THE VARIETY. He having commanded to give him my true o|pinion of it.
div.l: I Could not think theſe ſeven yeares, but that I
In part a Poet was, and ſo might lie,
By the Poetick Licence. But I finde
Now I am none, and strictly am confin'd
To truth, if therefore I ſubpaena'd were
Before the Court of Chancerie to ſwear.
Or if from thence I ſhould be higher ſent,
And on my life unto a Parliament
Of wit and judgement, there to certifie
What I could ſay of your VARIETY:
I would depoſe each Scene appear'd to me
An Act of wit, each Act a Comedy,
And all was ſuch, to all that underſtood,
As knowing Johnſon, ſwore By God 'twas good.

list.item: Rooksbill, a great Builder in Covent-Garden.
Croſſewill, a Countrey Gentleman, Lodger in his Buildings.
Cockbrain, a Juſtice of Peace, the Weeder of the Garden.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: _I Marry Sir! This is ſomething like! Theſe appear like Buildings! Here's Architecture expreſt in|deed! It is a moſt ſightly ſcitua|tion, and fit for Gentry and Nobility.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: When it is all finiſhed, doubtleſſe it will be handſome.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
It will be glorious: and yond magnificent Peece, the Piazzo, will excel that at Venice, by hear|ſay, (I ne're travell'd). A hearty bleſſing on their braines, honours, and wealths, that are Projectors, Furtherers, and Performers of ſuch great works. And now I come to you Mr. Rookesbill: I like your Rowe of houſes moſt incomparably. Your money never
ſhone ſo on your Counting-boards, as in thoſe Stru|ctures.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I have pil'd up a Leaſh of thouſand pounds in walls and windows there.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: It will all come again with large en|creaſe.

And better is your money thus let out on red and white, then upon black and white, I ſay. You can|not think how I am taken with that Rowe! How even and ſtraight they are! And ſo are all indeed. The Surveyor (what e're he was) has manifeſted himſelf the Maſter of his great Art. How he has wedded ſtrength to beauty; ſtate to uniformity; commodi|ouſneſſe with perſpicuity! All, all as't ſhould be!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: If all were as well tenanted and inhabited by worthy perſons.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Phew; that will follow. What new Planta|tion was ever peopled with the better ſort at firſt; nay, commonly, the lewdeſt blades, and naughty|packs are either neceſſitated to 'hem, or elſe do prove the moſt forward venturers. Is not lime and hair the firſt in all your foundations? do we not ſoile or dung our lands, before we ſowe or plant any thing that's good in 'hem? And do not weeds creep up firſt in all Gardens? and why not then in this? which never was a Garden until now; and which will be the Gar|den of Gardens, I foreſee't. And for the weeds in it, let me alone for the weeding of them out. And ſo as my Reverend Anceſtor Juſtice Adam Overdoe, was wont to ſay, In Heavens name and the Kings, and for the good of the Common-wealth I will go a|bout it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p:
I would a few more of the Worſhipful here|abouts, (whether they be in Commiſſion or not) were as well minded that way as you are Sir; we ſhould
then have all ſweet and clean, and that quickly too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I have thought upon a way for't, Mr. Rooks|bill: and I will purſue it, viz. to finde out all the enormities, yet be my ſelfe unſpied: whereby I will tread out the ſpark of impiety, whileſt it is yet a ſpark and not a flame; and break the egge of a miſ|chief, whileſt it is yet an egge and not a Cockatrice. Then doubt not of worthy tenants for your houſes Mr. Rooksbill.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, your beſt furtherance.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I had a letter bur laſt night from a worthy friend, a Weſt-countrey Gentleman, that is, now coming up with his family to live in Town here; and deſire is to inhabit in theſe buildings. He was to lie at Hammerſmith laſt night, and requeſted an early meeting of me this morning here, to aſſiſt him in the taking of a houſe. It is my buſineſſe hither; for he could never do't himſelfe. He has the oldeſt touchy, wrangling humour.—But in a harmleſſe way; for he hurts no body, and pleaſes himſelf in it. His children have all the trouble of it, that do anger him in obeying him ſometimes. You will know him anon. I mean, he ſhall be your Tenant. And luckily he comes.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: It is not enough you tell me of obedience. Or that you are obedient. But I will be obeyed in my own way. Do you ſee—

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: My noble friend Mr. Croſwill, right happi|ly met.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Your troubleſome friend Mr. Cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
No trouble at all, Sir, though I have pre|vented
yours in finding a fit houſe for you.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: You ha' not ha' you, ha?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Actum eſt Mr. Croſwill. But Civility par|don me, Is not this your daughter?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: All the Shee-things I have: and would I were well rid of her too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs. Katherine, Welcome—Mr. Gabriel, I take it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Gabriel Croſwill is my name.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: But where's your younger ſonne Mihill? There's a ſpark!

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: A Spark! A dunce I fear by this time like his brother Sheepſhead there.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Gabriel is my proper name.

sp.speaker: Groſ.
sp.p: I have not ſeen him this Twelve-moneth, ſince I chamber'd him a Student here in Town.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: In town, and I not know it?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: He knows not yet of my coming neither, nor ſhall not, till I ſteal upon him; and if I finde him mopiſh like his brother, I know what I will doe.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Have you not heard from him lately?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Yes, often by his letters, leſſe I could reade more comfort in 'hem. I fear he's turn'd Preciſian, for all his Epiſtles end with Amen; and the-matter of 'hem is ſuch as if he could teach me to ask him bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: A comfortable hearing of a young man.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
Is it ſo Sir? but I'le new mould him if it be ſo.—I'le tell you Mr. Cockbrayne; never was ſuch a father ſo croſt in his children. They will not obey me in my way. I grant, they do things that other fathers would rejoyce at. But I will be obeyed in my own way, dee ſee. Here's my eldeſt ſonne. Mark how he ſtands, as if he had learn't a poſture at Knights-bridge
ſpittle as we came aloug while-eare. He was not only borne without wit, but with an obſtinate re|ſolution, never to have any. I mean, ſuch wit as might become a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Was that reſolution borne in him think you.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: It could never grow up in him ſtill as it does elſe. When I would have him take his horſe, and follow the dogs, and aſſociate Gentlemen, in hawk|ing, hunting, or ſuch like exerciſes, he'l run you a foot five mile another way, to meet the brethren of the ſeparation, at ſuch exerciſes as I never ſent him to (I am ſure) on worky dayes. And whereas moſt Gentlemen run into other mens books, in hands that they care not who reades, he has a book of his own Short-writing in his pocket, of ſuch ſtuffe as is fit for no mans reading indeed but his own.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surely Sir.—

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Sure you are an Aſſe. Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You are my father.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: What comfort ſhould I have, were my ſon ſuch.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: And he has nothing but hang'd the head, as you ſee now, ever ſince Holiday ſports were cried up in the Countrey. And but for that, and to talk with ſome of the ſilenc'd Paſtors here in town about it, I ſhould not have drawn him up.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I would I could change a ſonne w' you Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What kinde of thing is thy ſonne? ha! doſt thou look like one that could have a ſonne fit for me to father, ha? And yet the beſt take both, and t' pleaſe you at all adventures, ha?

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I am ſure there cannot be a worſe, or more debauch'd reprobate then mine is living.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
And is the devil too good a Maſter for
him, think'ſt thou, ha? Wherein can I deſerve ſo ill at thy hands, fellow, whate're thou art, that thou ſhould'ſt wiſh me comber'd with a worſe burden, when thou heareſt me complain of this, ha? What is this fellow that you dare know him, Friend Cock|brayn? I will not dwell within three pariſhes of him.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: My tenant! Bleſſe me from him. I had ra|ther all my Rents were Bawdy houſes.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Think nothing of his words, he'll forget all inſtantly. The beſt natur'd man living.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Doſt thou ſtand like a ſon now that hears his father abuſ'd, ha?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I am praying for the converſion of the young man he ſpeaks of.

sp.speaker: Coek.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Mr. Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: But by the way, where's your ſonne Antho|ny? have you not heard of him yet?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Never ſince he forſook me, on the diſcon|tent he took, in that he might not marry your daugh|ret there. And where he lives, or whether he lives or not, I know not. I hope your davghter is a comfort to you.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Yes, in keeping her chamber whole weeks together, fullenning upon her Samplery breech-work, when I was in hope ſhe would have made me a Grand|father ere now. But ſhe has a humour, forſooth, ſince we put your ſon by her, to make me a match-broker, her marriage-Maker; when I tell you friend, there has been ſo many untoward matches of Pa|rents making, that I have ſworn ſhe ſhall make her own choice, though it be of one I hate. Make me her match-maker! Muſt I obey her, or ſhe me, ha?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I wiſh, with teares, my ſonne had had her now.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Wherein Sir, (under correction do I diſobey you?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: In that very word, under correction, thou diſ|obey'ſt me. Are you to be under correction at theſe yeares? ha! If I ha' not already taught you manners beyond the help of correction, go, ſeek a wiſer father to mend 'hem.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yet give me leave, dear Sir, in my ex|cuſe.—

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Leave out correction then.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: If I were forward as many Maidens are,
To wiſh a husband, muſt I not be ſought?
I never was a Gadder: and my Mother,
Before ſhe dy'd, adjur'd me to be none.
I hope you'll give me leave to keep your houſe.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: La there again! How ſubtly ſhe ſeeks dominion over me! No, huſwife, No; you keep no houſe of mine. I'll neſtle you no longer under my wing. Are you not fledge; I'll have you fly out I, as other mens daughters do; and keep a houſe of your own if you can find it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: We had a kinſwoman flew out too late|ly, I take it.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What tell'ſt thou me of her; wiſe-acres? Can they not flie out a little, but they muſt turne arrant vvhores, ha? Tell me of your kinſwoman? 'Tis true, ſhe was my Neece; ſhe vvent to't a little afore her time? ſome tvvo years ſince, and ſo fled from Re|ligion; and is turn'd Turk, vve fear. And vvhat of that in your preciſiancial vviſdom? I have ſuch children as no man has. But (as I vvas ſaying,) vvould ye top me husvvife, ha! Look you, novv I chide her, ſhe ſayes nothing. Is this obedience, ha?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Perhaps, I might unfortunately caſt my affecti|on on a man that vvould refuſe me.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: That man I vvould deſire to knovv; ſhevv me that man; ſee if I ſvvinge him not dares ſlight my daughter.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Still the old humour, ſelf-vvill'd, croſſe, and touchie; but ſuddainly reconcil'd. Come, Mr. Croſ|wil, to the buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Oh, you told me of a houſe you had found for me.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Yes Sir. And here's the Landlord.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Does he look, or go like one could let a houſe vvorthy of me.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Sir, vve have able Builders here, that vvill not carry leaſt ſhevv of their buildings on their backs. This is a rich ſufficient man, I aſſure you, and my friend.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I cry him heartily mercy, and embrace him. And novv I note you better, you look like Thrift it ſelf.
sp.stage: Enter Dorcas above upon a Bellconie. Gabriel gazes at her. Dorcas is habited like a Curtizan of Venice.
sp.p: I cannot think you vvill throvv avvay your houſes at a caſt. You have a ſonne, perhaps, that may, by the commendations you gave of him. Lets ſee your houſe.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Come avvay Mr. Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Come Sir, vvhat do you gape a●d ſhake the head at there? I'll lay my life he has ſpied the little Croſſe upon the nevv Church yond, and is at defiance vvith it. Sirrah, I vvill make you honour the firſt ſyllable of my name. My name is Will. Croſwill, and I vvill have my humour. Let thoſe that talk of me for it, ſpeak their pleaſure, I vvill do mine.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I ſhall obey you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Novv you are in the right. You ſhall indeed. I'll make your heart ake elſe, dee ſee.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
But truly I vvas looking at that Image; that
painted idolatrous image yonder, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O hereſie! It is ſome Lady, or Gentlewo|man ſtanding upon her Bellconey.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Her Bellconey? Where is it? I can ſpy from her foot to her face, yet I can ſee no Bellconey ſhe has.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What a Knave's this: That's the Bellconey ſhe ſtands on, that which jets out ſo on the forepart of the houſe; every houſe here has one of 'hem.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: 'Tis very good; I like the jetting out of the forepart very well; it is a gallant faſhion indeed.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I gueſs what ſhe is, what ere I have ſaid. O Juſtice look to thine office.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Come now to this houſe, and then to my ſon Mihil, the Spark you ſpoke of. And if I find him croſs too, I'le croſs him: Let him look to't▪ Dee ſee.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I'le ſee you hous'd; and then about my pro|ject, which is for weeding of this hopeful Garden. Ex. omnes.
sp.stage: Gabriel ſtayes last looking up at her.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Why ſhould not we in England uſe that free|dome
The famous Curtezans have in Italy:
We have the art, and know the Theory
To allure and catch the wandring eyes of Lovers;
Yea, and their hearts too: but our ſtricter Lawes
Forbids the publique practiſe, our deſires
Are high as theirs; our wills as apt and forward;
Our wits as ripe, our beauties more attractive;
Or Travellers are ſhrewd lyars. Where's the let?
Only in baſhful coward cuſtome, that
Stoops i'the ſhoulders, and ſubmits the neck
To bondage of Authority; to theſe Lawes,
That men of feeble age and weaker eye-ſight
Have fram'd to bar their ſons from youthful pleaſures.
Poſſets and Cawdels on their queaſie ſtomacks,
Whilſt I fly out in brave rebellion;
And offer, at the leaſt, to break theſe ſhackles
That holds our legs together: And begin
A faſhion, which purſu'd by Cyprian Dames,
May perſwade Juſtice to allow our Games.
Who knows? I'le try. Franciſca bring my Lute.
sp.stage: while ſhe is tuning her Lute: Enter Nich. Rookesbill, Anthony in a falſe beard, Clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Troth I have a great mind to be one of the Philoblathici, a Brother of the Blade and Battoon, as you tranſlate it; now ye have beat it into my head: But I fear I ſhall never come on and off handſomely. I have mettal enough methinks, but I know not how methinks to put it out.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: We'l help you out with it, and ſet it flying for you never doubt it.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Obotts, you mean my money mettal, I mean my valour mettal I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Peace, heark.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: T'other flyes faſt enough already.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Pox on ye peace.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O moſt melodious.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Moſt odious, Did you ſay? It is methinks moſt odoriferous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What new deviſe can this be? Look!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: She is vaniſht. Is't not the Mountebanks Wife that was here; and now come again to play ſome new merry tricks by herſelf.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A botts on't, I never ſaw that Mountebank; they ſay, he brought the firſt reſort into this new plan|tation, and ſow'd ſo much ſeed of Knavery and Co|zenage here, that 'tis fear'd 'twill never out.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay but this creature: What can ſhe be?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And then again, he drew ſuch flocks of idle people to him, that the Players, they ſay, curſt him abhominably.

sp.speaker: Ant,
sp.p: Thou ever talk'ſt of the wrong matter.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Cry mercy Brothers of the Blade and Bat|toune: Do you think if I give my endeavour to it, I ſhall ever learn to roar and carry it as you do, that have it naturally, as you ſay.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes, as we'll beat it into you. But this wo|man, this muſical woman, that ſet her ſelf out to ſhow ſo, I would be ſatisfied in her.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And ſhe be as able as ſhe ſeems, ſhe has in her to ſatisfie you, and you were a Brother of ten Blades, and ten Battounes.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow—Peace. I'le battoune thy teeth into thy tongue elſe; ſhe bears a ſtately preſence. Thou never ſaw'ſt her before: Didſt thou Toney?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No; but I heard an inkling at the Paris Tavern laſt night of a She-Gallant-that had travelled France and Italy; and that ſhe would—

sp.speaker: (Clot.
sp.p: Battoun thy teeth into thy tongue.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Plant ſome of her forraign collections, the fruits of her travels, in this Garden here, to try how they would grow or thrive on Engliſh earth.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Young Pig was ſpeaking of ſuch a one to me, and that ſhe was a Mumper.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: What's that a Siſter of the Scabberd, brother of the Blade?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come, come; we'l in, we'l in; 'tis one of our fathers buildings; I'le ſee the Inhabitants. Some money Clot. furniſh I ſay, and quickly.—I vow—

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You ſhall, you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What ſhall I?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Vow twice before you have it.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow, and I vow again, I'le coyn thy brains.—

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Hold, hold, take your powl money; I thought I would have my will; and the word I look-for, I'le coyn thy brains.—

I do not love to give my money for nothing, I have a volume of words here, the worſt of 'hem is as good as a blow; and then I ſave my Crown whole half a dozen times a day, by half a crown a time, there's half in half ſav'd by that.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come let's appear civil, till we have our en|trance, and then as occaſion ſerves—
Who would you ſpeak withal?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Your Miſtreſs, little one.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Do you know her Sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No; but I would know her, that's the buſi|neſs: I mean the muſical Gentlewoman that was fidling, and ſo many in the What-doe-call't een now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What-doe-call her Sir, I pray?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What-doe-call her; 'tis not come to that yet, prethee let me ſee and ſpeak with her firſt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You are diſpos'd I think.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What ſhould we do here elſe?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: You wont thruſt in upon a body whether one will or no.

sp.speaker: Ant. Nic.
sp.p: Away you Monkey.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: O me, What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O my brave Philoblathici.—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What's the matter the Girl cryes out ſo?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I know not: I fear ſome rude company, ſome of the wild crew are broke into the houſe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Within. Whether would you go, you wont rob the houſe will ye?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Will ye be quiet Whiskin?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O me 'tis ſo: Hell's broke looſe; this comes of your new fingle-fangle faſhion, your prepoſtrous Italian way forſooth: would I could have kept my old way of pots and pipes, and my Strong-water courſe for cuſtomers: The very firſt twang of your fiddle guts has broke all, and conjur'd a legion of de|vils among us.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Nay, there's but a Leaſh of us. How now?
Who have we here? Are theſe the far travel'd Ladies?
O thou party perpale, or rather parboild Bawd.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What ſhall I do? Dam. Out alaſs; ſure they are devils indeed.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Art thou travel'd croſs the Seas from the Bankſide hither, old Counteſs of Codpiece-row?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Party perpale and parboild Bawd.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And is this the Damſel that has been in France and Italy? Clot. Codpiece-row.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Peace ye roaring Scabs: I'le beſworn ſhe ſupt at Paris Tavern laſt night, and lay not long ago at the Venice by Whitefryers Dock.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Prethee what is ſhe Madge?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: A civil Gentlewoman you ſee ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: She has none of the beſt faces: but is ſhe war|rantable; I have not had a civil night theſe three moneths.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Nor none are like to have here, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O Madge how I do long thy thing to ding didle ding.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: O Nick, I am not in the humour, no more is ſhe to be o'the merry pin now; I am ſure her caſe is too lamentable. But if you will all ſit down, I'le give you a bottle of wine, and we'l relate her ſtory to you, ſo you will be civil. Nic. Well for once, I care not if we be.
sp.stage: A Table bottle, light, and Tobacco ſtales.
sp.p: Let us ſet to't then; ſit down brother Toney, ſit down Gentlewoman, we ſhall know your name a|non, I hope it will fall in your ſtory; ſit down Clot|poll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You will call me brother Clotpoll too when I have taken my oath, and paid my entrance into the faternity of the Blade and the Battoun.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: 'Tis like we ſhall. Now Lady of the Stygian Lake, thou black infernal Madge, begin the diſmal ſtory, whilſt I begin the bottle.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: This Gentlewoman whoſe name is Damyris.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Damyris ſtay. Her nick-name then is Dammy, ſo we may call her when we grow familiar: and to begin that familiarity, Dammy here's to you.—drink.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And what's your nick-name I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nick: only Nick, Madge there knows it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Then I believe your name is Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow-witty. Yes Dammy, and my Sirname is Rookesbill, and ſo is my Fathers too: and what do you make o'that?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Nothing not I Sir: ſure this is he.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: And I would he were nothing, ſo I had all he has: I muſt have tother glaſs to waſh him out of my mouth, he furs it worſe then Mondongas Tobacco. Here old Madge, and to all the birds that ſhall won|der at thy howletſhip, when thou rid'ſt in an Ivy-buſh, call'd a Cart.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Well mad Nick, I'le pledge thee in hope to ſee as many flutter about the tree, that thou ſhalt clime backwards.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A pox thou wilt be ſtifled with Offal and Car|ret leaves before that day.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fie, fie, what talk's this? 'tis he I am conſi|dent.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Theſe are our ordinary complements, we wiſh no harm.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No Dammy I vow, not I to any breathing.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But your Father Nick.—Is he that Rookeſ|bill.—

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: But my Fathet; Pox rot ye, why do ye put me in mind of him again, he ſticks i'my throat, now I'le waſh him a little further.—Here Brother Toney

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Gramercy Brother Nick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And to all the brothers that are, and are to be of the Blade and the Battoun.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: There ſaid you well Clotpoll: Here 'tis—

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I would but have asked you whether your Father were that Rookesbill that is call'd the great Builder.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p:
Yes marry is it he forſooth; he has built I know not how many houſes hereabout, though he goes Dammy as if he were not worth a groat; and all his cloaths I vow are not worth this hilt, except thoſe he wears, and prayes for fair weather in, on my Lord Mayors Day; and you are his Tenant, though perhaps you know it not, and may be mine; therefore uſe me well: for this houſe and the reſt I hope will be mine, as well as I can hope he is mortal, of which I muſt confeſs I have been in ſome doubt, though now I hope again, he will be the firſt ſhall lay his bones i'the new Church, though the Church-yard be too good
for him before 'tis conſecrated. So give me the to-the cup, for now he offends my ſtomack. Here's to thee now Clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And to all the Siſters of the Scabberd Bro|ther in Election. Dee hear, Pray talk of his father no more, for the next brings him to the belly-work, and then he'll drink him quite through him.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And ſo we ſhall have a foul houſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No he ſhall ſtick there. Now to the ſtory Gentlewoman, 'twas that we ſate for.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I to the ſtory, I vow I had almoſt forgot it; and I am the worſt at Sack in a morning: Dear Dam|my to the ſtory.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Good Sir my heart's too full to utter't.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Troth and my head's too full to hear it: But I'le go out and quarrel with ſome body to ſettle my brains, then go down to Mich. Croſſewill to put him in mind of our meeting to day; then if you will meet me at the Goat at Dinner, wee'll have it all at large.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Will you be there indeed Sir, I would ſpeak with you ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Dammy if I be not, may my father out live me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We both here promiſe you he ſhall be there by noon.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: 'Lady, 'tis ſworn by Blade and by Battoun.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: This will be the braveſt diſcovery for Mihill, the new Italian Bona Roba Catſoe.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Why ſo ſad on the ſuddain Niece.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: But do you think hee'll come as he has pro|mis'd.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: He never breaks a promiſe with any of us' though he fail all the honeſt part o'the world: But I truſt you are not taken with the Ruffian, you'll nere get penny by him.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I prethee peace, I care not.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But Myſtris, rhere is a Gallant now below, a Gingle boy indeed, that has his pockets full of, crowns that chide for vent. Shall I call him up to you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I will ſee no man.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: How's that? I hope you jeſt.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Indeed, I hope you jeſt.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: You will not hinder the houſe, I hope. Marry heigh. This were a humour and 'twould laſt. Go fetch him up.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'le flie then out at window. Nay, by this ſteel 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What's the matter? have I got a mad wo|man into the houſe. What do you go about to break me the firſt day of your coming, before you have han|ſell'd a Couch or a Bedſide in't. Were you but now all o'th heigh to ſet your ſelf out for a ſigne with your fiddle cum twang, and promiſe ſuch wonders, for|ſooth, and will not now be ſeen. Pray what's the Riddle.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'll tell thee all anon. Prithie excuſe me. I know thy ſhare of his ſins bounty would not come to thus much, take it, I give it thee. And prithee let me be honeſt till I have a mince to be otherwiſe, and I'le hinder thee nothing.

sp.speaker: M●d.
sp.p: Well, I'le diſmiſſe the Gallant, and ſend you, Sirrah, for another wench. I'le have Beſſe Bufflehead again. This kickſy wincy Giddibrain will ſpoil all I'le no more Italian tricks.—
sp.l: Thus ſome have by the phrenſie of deſpair
Fumouſly run into the ſea to throw
Their wretched bodies, but when come near
They ſaw the billows riſe, heard Boreas blow,
And horrid death appearing on the Maine,
A ſudden fear hath ſent them back again.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: NAy, but honeſt Shoomaker; thy honeſt price.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I tell you intruth, Sir, 'tis as good a boot as e|ver you pull'd on in your life.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A little too ſtreight, I doubt. What do you think o' my boots honeſt Tailor.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: They do exceeding handſomely, never truſt me Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Never fear it Tailor, you ſhall truſt me, and pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: You are pleaſant Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And what do you think of my ſuite Shooma|ker? can you ſay as much for the Tailor as he for you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A very neat ſuite, Sir, and becomes you ex|cellent.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Honeſt men both, and hold together; one would little think you were ſo near neighbours. Well, you, have fitted me both, I muſt confeſſe. But how I ſhall fit you, now there's the point.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: There's but one way for than and pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: With paying us our money Sit.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Still both in a tale, I can not but commend your neighbourhood, I muſe my Laundreſſe ſtayes,
I ſent her three or foure wayes for moneys. But do not you ſtay for that. I have wayes enough to pay you. I have ploughes a going that you dream not of.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, we dream of nothing but ready money, ſleeping or waking.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I ſhall be rich enough ne're fear't. I have a venter in the new ſoap buſineſſe man.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: We are but ſervants, Sir. And our Ma|ſters themſelves have no faith, in flippery pro|jects.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Beſides, the women begin to grumble a|gainſt that ſlippery project ſhrewdly, and, 'tis feard, will mutinie ſho tly.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Burlakin, and they may prove more trouble|ſome then a commotion of Sailors.
O welcome, Laundreſſe, where's the money.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Not a penny of money, Sir, can I get. But here's one come to town has brought you enough, and you can have grace to finger it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Who's that I prithee.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Your father, your father Sir. I met his man by great chance, who told me his Maſter meanes to ſteal upon you preſently, and take you as he findes you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Is he come up with his croſſe tricks. I hea●d he was to come. And that he meanes to live here altogether. He has had an aime theſe dozen years to live in town here, but never was fully bent on't un|til the Proclamation of reſtraint ſpurr'd him up. 'Tis ſuch a Croſſewill. Well, he is my father, and I am utterly undone if thou help'ſt me not now at a pinch, at a pinch, dear Laundreſſe. Go borrow me a Gown,
and ſome foure or five Law-books? for, I proteſt, mine are in Duck-lane. Nay, trudge, ſweet Laun|dreſſe, trudge.— Ex. Laun. Honeſt Tailor and Shoemaker convey your ſelves away quietly, and I'll pay you to morrow, as I am a Gentleman:

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: As I am a Shoemaker, and that's a kinde of a Centleman, you know, I'll not ſtirre till I have my money, I am not an Aſſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No body ſayes thou art.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: I have had too many ſuch tricks put upon me i' my dayes.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A trick! as I hope for money it is no trick.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: Well Sir, trick or no trick. I muſt have my money or my boots, and that's plain dealing.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A pox o'th' boots, ſo my legs were out of 'hem. Would they were i'thy throat, ſpurres and all, you will not out.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: No marry will we not.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Well-ſaid Shoomaker, I commend thee, thou haſt a better heart then I, though my ſtomack's good.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: O well ſaid, my good Laundreſſe. How am I bound to thee; yet all this wo'not do't Laundreſſe. Thou muſt beſtir thy ſtumps a little further, and bor|row me a couple of Gownes more for theſe Raſcals here that will not away.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: How! wo'not away? And they were well ſerv'd, they would be thruſt out of doors for ſaucie companions. Your Maſters would not put a Gentle|man to his trumps thus.

sp.speaker: M;.
sp.p:
Nay, ſvveet Laundreſſe, reſtrain thy tongue, and ſtretch thy feet. A couple of Govvns, good
Laundreſſe, and forget not caps. Ex. If I do novv furniſh you like Civil Lavvyers, and you do not keep your countenances; if ever you do but peep in at the Hall-door at Chriſtmas to ſee the revels, I'le have you ſet i'th' ſtocks for this beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: If you do, Sir, I may hap be even vvith you before the year comes about, and ſet you in our ſtocks for't.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: But will you make Lawyers of us.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Have you a minde to have your money you unbelieving Raſcals.

sp.speaker: Shoc.
sp.p: I ſee your drift, and hope you'll prove an honeſt Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thou haſt ſome hope, though no faith nor truſt in any man.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, our Maſters ſit at grear rents, and keep great families.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, they are remov'd into the nevv plantation here, where, they ſay, are a tribe of Infidel-tradeſmen, that have made a Law vvithin your ſelves to put no truſt in Gentlemen. But beare your ſelves handſomely here you vvere beſt. I am acquainted vvith a crevv that haunts about your ha|bitations, vvith whom I will joyne, and ſo batter your windows one of theſe nights elſe.—O welcom, Laundreſſe, how doeſt thou toile for me.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Your fathers talking, as I am a woman, be|low.—As thou art a woman below, well-ſaid. Come on with theſe Gownes, and lets ſee how yow'll look. If we had time, the Shoomaker ſhould waſh his face; but ſeeing there is no remedy; pull the cap in your eyes, and good enongh. Now Laun|dreſſe, ſet us ſtooles, and leave us.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: I hear him coming up.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Now let him come, we are ready for him. Shoomaker, keep your hand underneath the
book, that the pitch do not diſcover you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And Taylor, be ſure you have no Needle on your ſleeve, nor thread about your neck.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I warrant you too for me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.p: He's enrred.
sp.stage: Enter Croſwill, Belt, and ſtand aſide.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Remitter, I ſay, is where a man hath two titles, that is to ſay, one of an elder, the other of a later. And he cometh to the land by the later title; yet the Law adjudgeth him to be in by the force of the elder title. If the tenant in the taile diſcontinee the taile, and after he diſeaſeth his diſ|continue, and ſo dieth ſeiſed, whereby the tenants deſcend to their iſſue, as to his Couſin inheritable by force of the taile. In this caſe the tenants deſcend, who have right by force of the taile, a Remitter in the taile taken for that in the Law, ſhall put and ad|judge him to be in by force of deſcent. Pox on ye, ſpeak ſomething good or bad, ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The Remitter, you ſay, is ſeiſed i'th' tail.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Excellent Shoomaker, I ſay ſo, and again, I ſay, that if the tenant in the taile in feoffe his ſon, or his Couſin, inheritable by force of the taile, the which ſonne or couſin at the time of the feoffment is within age, and after the tenant in the taile dierh, this is a Remitter to the heire in the taile to whom the feoffment is made, now Taylor.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Think you ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Look either Fitzherbert, Perkins, or Dier, and you ſhall finde it in the ſecond part of Richard Cordelyon. So much for Remitter. Novv I'll put a plain home-ſpun caſe, as a man may ſay, vvhich vve call a moot-caſe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I pray do Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Some father might take joy of ſuch a ſonne novv. This takes not me. No, this is not my vvay.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: The caſe is this
pull up your grounds cloſer and behang'd, you are a Tailor, and you: a Shoomaker.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And you owe us money.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I put the caſe, I do, to you for a ſuit of clothes.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And to you for a paire of boots.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I have broke my day with you both. Sup|poſe ſo.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Very well, we do.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You clap a Sergeant o' my back. I put in bail, remove it, and carry it up into the upper Court, with habeas-Corpus; bring it down again into the lower Court with procedendo; then take it from thence, and bring it into the Chancery with a Cer|tiorari; I; and if you look not to ●t, bring it out of the Chancery again, and thus will I keep you from your money till your ſuite and your boots be worne out before you recover penny of me.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: S●ly'd but you ſhall not, your father ſhall know all firſt.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: S'foot Shoomaker wilt thou be an Aſſe. I do but put a caſe, Have you not feen it tried.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Yes, very often.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p:
Away with books. Away with Law. Away with madneſſe. I, God bleſſe thee, and make thee his ſervant, and defend thee from Law, I ſay. Take up theſe books, ſarrah, and carry them preſently into Pauls Church-yard dee ſee, and change them all for Hiſto|ries, as pleaſant as profitable; Arthur of Britain,
Primalion of Greece, Amadis of Gaul, and ſuch like de ſee.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope he do's but jeſt.

sp.speaker: Croſs.
sp.p: And do you heare, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Get Bells work, and you can, into the bar|gain.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Which Bell, Sir? Adam Bell, with Clim ●'th' Clough, and William of Cloudeſley.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Adam Bell you Aſſe? Valiant Bell that kill'd the Dragon.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: You mean St. George.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Sir Jolthead, do I not. I'le teach you to chop logick, vvith me.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot, how ſhall I anſwer my borrow'd books? Stay Belt. Pray Sir, do not change my books.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, I will change them and you too: Did I leave thee here to learn faſhions and manners, that thou mightſt carry thy ſelf like a Gentleman, and doſt thou waſt thy brains in learning a language that I underſtand not a word of? ha! I had been as good have brought thee up among the wild Iriſh.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Why alaſs Sir, Had I not better keep my ſelf within my Chamber, at my Studie, then be rioting a|broad, waſting both money and time, which is more precious then money? if you did know the inconve|nience of company, you would rather incourage and commend my retir'd life, then any wayes dehort me from it.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Why Sir did not I keep companie think you when I was young? Ha!

sp.speaker: Ml.
sp.p: Yes Sir; but the times are much alter'd, and youth more corrupted now, they did not drink and wench in thoſe dayes, but nay, o 'tis abominable in theſe.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
Why this is that I fear'd, the boyes turning
meacock too, after his elder brother, 'twas time to look to him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why Croſwill Mich. What, not up yet and behang'd. Or ha ye a wench a bed wye. Is this keep|ing your home. Mihil runs to the door and holds it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot the Rogue Rooksbil and his crew, I fear'd as much.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Break open the door, let me come to't.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Forbear, or behang'd, you will undo me, my father's here. I'll meet you anon as I am honeſt.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Your father's a Clowterdepouch. Nay, I will come then, what Madamoiſelle do you call fa|ther.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You would not believe me. Pray be civil.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo, we will Cry mercy, you are buſie, we will not moote to day then?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope you may excuſe me, I'le be w'ye a|non.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come to the Goat Capricorne. We have the braveſt new diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: How now! what are theſe?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: They are Gentlemen of my ſtanding, Sir, that have a little over-ſtudied themſelves, and are ſome|what—.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Mad; are they not? And ſo will you be ſhortly, if you follow theſe courſes. Mooting do they call it? you ſhall moote nor mute here no long|er. Therefore on with your cloak and ſword, follow me to the Tavern and leave me ſuch long-tail'd com|pany as theſe are, for I do not like them.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No more do I, Sir, if I knew how to be rid of 'hem.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I think thou haſt ne're a ſword, haſt thou, ha?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Where is it, Sir, let me ſe't Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'Tis here, under mybed, Sir.—Reach it.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Why there's a Lawyers trick right, make his weapon companion with his Piſſe-pot. Fie, fie, here's a tool indeed. There's money, Sir, buy you a good one, one with the Mathematical hilt as they terme it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: It would do better in Mathematical books▪ Sir, offer me no money, pray Sir, but for books.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Go to, you are a peeviſh Jack, do not pro|voke me: do not you owe me obedience? ha!

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: 'Tis good you do. Well, take that money; and put your ſelfe into cloathes befitting your rank, Do ſo. And let me ſee you, ſquirting about without a weapon, like an Attorneys Clerk in Tearm-time, and I'l weapon you, What, ſhall I have a Noddie of you. This frets him to the liver. Go to, never hang the head for the matter. For I tell thee I will have it ſo, and herein be knowen what I am.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You are known ſufficiently for your croſſe humour already; in which I'll try you if I can make you double this money, for this will not ſerve my turne.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What have you told it after me, you had beſt weigh it too.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No Sir, but I have computed that for my pre||ſent uſe, here is too much by halfe, pray Sir, take halfe back.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Bodie o' me, what a perverſe knave is this, to croſſe me thus! Is there too much, ſay you? ha●

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes truly, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Let me ſee't. Go thy wayes, take thy mu|ſty books, and rhy ruſtie whittle here again. And take your fooliſh plodding dunci-coxcomely courſe, till I look after you again. Come away ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot, who's the Gull now? Taylor, Shoo|maker, you may go pawn your Gownes for any mo|ney I am like to have.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: We have all played the Lavvyers to pret|ty purpoſe, in pleading all this while for nothing. Well ſir, to avoid further trouble, I am content to withdravv my action, that is, pull off your boots a|gain, and be jogging.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And for my part, ſir, I can do no leſſe then take you by default and non-ſuit you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Very good Lavvyers both, Is my father quite gone Belt?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Gone in a tempeſt of high diſpleaſure, ſir: And has ſent you here all the money he had about him; and bids you refuſe it if you dare, 'tis above tvvice the ſumme he offered you before; but good ſir, do not refuſe it. He ſvvears he vvill try vvhe|ther you or he ſhall have his vvill. Take heed you croſſe him not too much.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Well at thy requeſt, becauſe thou ſhalt not have anger for carrying it back again, I vvill accept.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I thank you Sir. Conſider, he's your fa|ther, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
I do moſt Reverend Belt. and vvould be loth to croſſe him, although I may as much in taking his money as refuſing it, for ought I knovv, for thou knovv'ſt 'tis his cuſtome to croſſe me, and the reſt
of his children in all we do, to try and urge his obe|dience; 'tis an odde way: therefore to help my ſelf I ſeem to covet the things that I hate, and he pulls them from me; and makes ſhew of loathing the things I covet, and he hurles them doubly at me, as now in this money.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Are you ſo crafty?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes, but do thou put it in his head, and I'le pick out thy braines.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: You never knew an old Serving-man treache|rous to his young Maſter: what? to the hopes o'th' houſe; you will be heire, that's queſtionleſſe: for to your comfort, your elder brother growes every day more fool then the other. But now the reſt of the meſſage is, that you make haſte, and come to my Maſter to the Goat in Covent-Garden, where he dines with his new Landlord to day.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He has taken a houſe then.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O, a moſt delicate one, vvith a curious Belconee and all belonging to't moſt ſtately.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: At the Goat does he dine, ſayeſt thou.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: My crevv are gone thither too. Pray Mars vve fall not foule of one another. Well, go thy vvay, preſent my duty to him, I'le follovv preſentlie. Tell him I took his money vvith much unvvilling|neſſe.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: As Lavvyers do their fees. Let me alone ſir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Well Tailor and Shoomaker; you have put me to't, but here's your money.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: 'Twas for that we did put you to't Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Let's ſee your biil Tailor

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.p: Here 'tis, ſir, as ready as a Watchmans.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Then good vvords vvill paſſe it, 7 li. 4. ſh. tell your money; yours is 14 ſh. boots and Galloſhes.
There 'tis and 12. d. to drink.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: I thank your vvorſhip.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Are you right Tailor.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.p: Yes and pleaſe you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: There's a ſhilling for you too, to ſpend in bread.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: He knows both our diets. We'll make bold to take leave of your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Not ſo bold as I'm glad I'm too well rid of you, moſt courteous Gentlemen.

To ſee what money can do; that can change mens manners, alter their conditions: how tempeſtuous the ſlaves were without it. O thou powerful metal! what authority is in thee! Thou art the Key to all mens mouthes. With thee a man may lock up the jawes of an informer, and without thee he cannot the lips of a Lawyer.

div.head: Scoen. II.
div.stage: Enter Croſſewill, Rookesbill, Gabriel, Kathe|rine, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Down boy, and bid the Cook haſten din|ner.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: What will you pleaſe to drink in the mean time, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I will not drink in the mean time, ſir, Get you gone.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: A fine old humorous Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
Hold up your head, Sirrah, and leave your preciſe folly. I'll leave you to the wilde world elſe, dee ſee. Is the name of a Tavern ſo odious to you? Ha. Your brother has vext me ſufficiently alreadie, and perhaps he'll refuſe to come too! If he dares let him. Welcome Mr. Rooksbil, welcom Landlord, and your faire daughter, welcome pretty one. Truſt
me a pretty one indeed, pray be acquainted with my daughter there. In your Maiden-company, I hope ſhe will not think the Tavern ſuch a bugs neaſt as ſhe did. I had much ado to draw my rebellious chil|dren to the Tavern after me.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: And truly, ſir, 'tis the firſt to my knowledge that e're my daughter came into.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: All in good time, ſhe may encreaſe in ver|tue. But if it be a fault, (as i' my conſcience in his thought it is a great tranſgreſſion) my unſetledneſſe, and unprovidedneſſe elſe, where or how to entertain a friend, or feed my ſelfe, may well excuſe us all, dee ſee.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: O Sir, I cannot enough admire that vertue in your ſonne.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: It is a vice, as much a vice or more, as is your ſonnes, your caſt-aways as you call him, that ſucks no other ai●e, then that of Tavernes, Tap|houſes, Brothels, and ſuch like. I would their ex|tream qualities could meet each other at half-way, and ſo mingle their ſuperfluities of humour unto a mean betwixt 'hem. It might render them both al|lowable ſubjects, where now the one's a firedrake in the aire, and t'other a mandrake in the earth, both miſ|chievous, ſee how he ſtands like a mole-catcher. What dirty dogged humour vvas I in vvhen I got him troe?

sp.speaker: Rookeſ.
sp.p: Hovve're his carriage ſeems diſtaſteful un|to you, I could afford (vvith your allovvance, to make conditions of eſtate agreeable) to give all that is mine to him vvith my daughter.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
What a mechanick ſlave is this, to thank a ſonne of mine, hovve're I under-rate him, a fit mate to mingle blood vvith his moore-ditch breed. True, his eſtate is great, I underſtand it, but of all foule I love not Moor-hens. Such another motion
vvould ſtir me to roare him dovvn the tavern|ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: What do you think on't ſirs.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Heaven grant me patience.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: Will you conſider of it Maſter Croſſe|will.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I was never ſo put to't. I wiſh we had a ſtickler. I muſe that Maſter Cockbrayne ſtayes thus.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: You do not mind my motion ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Uds precious I minde nothing, I am ſo croſt in mind thar I can minde nothing, nor I will minde nothing, dee ſee. Why comes not Mr. Cockbrayue, Ha!

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: Yet you minde him it ſeems. But he, ſir, cannot come, and deſires you to hold him excuſ'd. He's gone about ſome ſpecial undertaking, for the good of the Common-wealth, he ſayes.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Fart for his undertaking; all the world is bent to croſſe me. What is my young Maſter come? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: My young Maſter Mr. Mihil will be here preſently, he ſaid he would follow me at heeles, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: And why not come before you, ſir. Does he not think that I have waited long enough, ſir? ſure I'll croſſe ſome body under that knaves pate of yours, d'y'fee.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Thus when any body angers him, I am ſure to hear on't.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: So now my ſpleen is a little palliated, let me ſpeak with you Mr. Rooksbill. Get you down, Sir|rah; and bring me word, dinner is not ready, and I'll give you as much more, d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: That's his way to his ſtomach.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And is your brother that your father ſayes is ſo ungracious, ſo well acquainted with my brother Mihil, ſay you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh all in all, he's not ſo familiar with any man, if Mihil Croſwill be your brother, as 'tis mani|feſt.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I would not that my father knew it, for all I can expect from him but his bleſſing, but does your father know it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, I would not he ſhould miſtruſt it for all he has, bleſſing and all; and now that I have found you love your brother fo well, I will make over my reaſon and my counſel in truſt with you, hoping you will not wrong that truſt.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: If I do, may the due price of treachery be my reward.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I love your brother, Lady, and he loves me. The only good act that ever my brother did, was to bring us acquainted, and is indeed all that he has to live on. For I do ſuccour him with many a ſtolne peece for the felicitie he brought me in your brothers love. Now, my father, whoſe irreconcileable hate has for e|ver diſcarded my brother, ſhould he but dream of their acquaintance, would poiſon all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But let me ask you, is there an hope betwixt you and my brother ever to come together?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, and a way he has for●t, which I under|ſtand not yet.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Truſt me, I pity you both, your caſe is very dangerous.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Love's above all adventures, the more hard the atchievement is, the ſweeter the reward.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I like her ſpirit well.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: You Sir, come hither, what is hammering in your head now?
Is't not ſome Synodical queſtion to put unto the brethren, concerning Whitſonales and Maygames? ha!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surely ſir, I was premeditating a fit thankſ|giving to be rendred before meat in. Tavernes, accord|ing to the preſent occaſion which the time and place ad|miniſtreth, and that as the ſpirit ſhall enable me, ſhall be delivered before you in due ſeaſon.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I am glad I know your minde; for that trick, my zealous ſonne, you ſhall come in at half-dinner, like a Chafing-diſh of coales, when the ſawce is cold, to make uſe of the heat of your ſpirit; d ye ſee. I love not meat twice dreſt.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Good ſir, put the Propoſition to him, that I made my affection to him, urges it more and more, I never was ſo taken with a man.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: But what's that to your daughter? ha!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: The ſame affection governes her, ſhe is not mine elſe.

sp.speaker: Croſ
sp.p: Well, hold your peace, and was that your ſpi|ritual meditation?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes, verily.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Come Sir, at this Gentlemans requeſt I will now put a queſtion to you concerning the fleſh. What, think you of yond Virgin there his daughter? can you affect her ſo well as to wiſh her to be your wedded wife?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You mean, elpouſed in holy Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Yes, I mean ſo.

p.hi: hum hum hum Pſalm tune. How happy.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: But do thou ſay, yes verily to that, and as I hope to have peace in my grave. I'll break the Kings peace on thy pate preſently.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is a weighty queſtion, and requires due pre|meditation in a religious anſwer, pray give me leave to take advice—

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: What ſayes he, Sir?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: He ſayes he will talk with a cunning man a|bout her.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Sure you miſtake him, ſir.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: You are welcome, Gentlemen. Will. Harry, Zachary.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Zachary is a good name.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Where are you? he (rings the bell) ſhew up into the Phoenix. Is the Checque empty?

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Hoyday, here's a din.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: A pottle of Canarie to the Dolphin, ſcore.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Y' are welcome, Gentlemen, take up the lil|lie-pot.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Half a dozen of clean pipes and a candle for the Elcphant. They take their own Tobaccho.

sp.speaker: Vint,
sp.p: Whoſe room do they foul Sirrah, Harry, Harry?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Do Elephants take Tobaccho?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Carry up a Jordan for the Maidenhead, and a quart of white muskadine for the blew Bore.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Now me thinks, the muskadine for tht Maidenhead, and the Jordan for the Bore were better.
Knock aboue, and a pot thrown. Why boyes, draw|er, rogues, take up, (below) By and by, by and by, (above) Wine, Tobaccho.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What variety of noiſes is here? and all excel|lent ill ſounds. (Above) Call up the Fidlers, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Such cries as theſe went forth before the deſo|lation of the great City.
O prophane tinkling the cymbals of Satan; that tickle the care with vanity, to lift up the mind to lewd|neſſe. Mine eares ſhall be that of the Adder againſt the Song of the Serpent.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: O rare, in a young man!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will roare out aloud to drown your Incan|tations. Yea, I will ſet out a throat even as the beaſt that belloweth.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Moſt happy youth!

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Hold your peace, Sirrah, or I'le make you bel|low for ſomething.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot-back, Nick to your own room. Thy father's here too, as I breath.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: My Lucie too, as I live. How the devil got they acquainted? Sure he's his Landlord 'Tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Dare you come, ſir, you ſhould have ſtayed now till you had been ſent for.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Verily, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Are you at your Verilies too? ha!

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: But for di●pleaſing you, I had rather have graz'd on Littletons Commons, or ha' faſted this fourt|night, then come for my repaſt into this Wilderneſſe; but you will ha' it ſo

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: You are in the right Sir, I'le have it ſo in|deed, I'le know why I ſhall not elſe. What do you know no bodie here?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I crie them mercie, my good brother,—and my loving ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: But what vertuous men has this man to his ſons, and how they thrive in grace againſt his will, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: What Gentlewoman is this of your acquaint|ance, Siſter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis well diſſembled brother, but I know your cunning.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Have you betray'd me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mum Mr. Mihil, mum.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: By and by.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: What devil art thou that roareſt in mine eare ſo.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Hold, I beſeech you, I come to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What, with a By and by, that ſtrikes into my head as ſharp as a Stellatto.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I come to tell you, ſir, that your table's co|vered in a fairer Room, and more private, your meat is ready to go up, and all in a readineſſe.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Now thou art an honeſt fellow, there's a couple of ſhillings for thee. Have us out of thy windmil here, I prithee, and thy By and by's.

div.head: Scoen 1.
div.stage: Enter Captain Driblow, Clotpoll, Nick, Anthony, Drawer, A Table, Pot and Glaſſes.
div.p: GO Sirrah, make your reckoning for our din|ner. Leave us this wine, and come when we call you. We have buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I ſhall, ſir, by and by.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, ſir, you will be of both you ſay, the Blade and the Battoon?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Of both, ſir, by all meanes, both Philoblathi|cus and Philobatticus, I. I'le now have all that be|longs to your order, or all my money again, that's for a certain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Your money again? loe you there. You bring me a fit man, Gentlemen to be ſworn, do you not? that talks of money again, when 'tis a main Article in the Oath, never to look for money again, once disfinger'd.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You will not ſpoil all now 'tis come ſo far? will you?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Well ſir, when I have my Oath, and that I am ſworn one of you. I'le do as you do, and care as little for money as he that has leaſt.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, to the Oath then, for both the Bſade and the Battoon you ſay?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I by all meanes, Captain, for both. S'lid the Battoon may ſtick to me, when the Blade may flie out o'th' Hilts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, to the Brokers.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Lay your hands on theſe Hilts, ſir. The Ar|ticles that you depoſe unto are theſe, To be true and faithful unto the whole Fraternity of the Blade and the Battoon, and to every member thereof.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: As ever faithful member was.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That at no time, wittingly or ignorantly, drunk or ſober, you reveal or make diſcovery of the Brother, or a member of the Brotherhood, of his lodg|ing, haunts, or by-walks, to any Creditor, Officer, Sut|ler, or ſuch like dangerous or ſuſpitious perſon.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I defie them all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That if any of the Brotherhood be in re|ſtraint or diſtreſſe by impriſonment, ſickneſſe, or whatſoever engagement, you make his caſe your own, and your purſe and your travel his; and that if a bro|ther die or finiſh his dayes, by end timely or untimelie, by Surfet, Sword, or Law. You wear the ſable order of the Riband in remembrance of him.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A convenient cheap way of mourning.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
That your purſe and weapon to the utmoſt
of your ſtrength, be on all occaſions drawn to the aſ|ſiſtance or defence of a Brother or Brothers friend, be it he, be it ſhe.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I underſtand you, and ſhall be as forward to fight for a She-friend, as ever the beſt man in the mir|rour of Knighthood was for an honeſt woman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That you be ever at deadly defiance with all ſuch people, as Protections are directed to in Parlia|ment, and that you watch all occaſions to prevent or reſcue Gentlemen from the gripes of the Law briſſons. That you may thereby endear your ſelfe into noble ſociety, and drink the juice of the Varlets labours for your officious intruſions.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And that will go down bravely.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You muſt rank your ſelf ſo much the better man, by how much the more drink you are able to purchaſe at others coſts.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Cupt.
sp.p: You are to let no man take wall of you, but ſuch as you ſuppoſe will either beat you or lend you money.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Better and better ſtill.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The reſt of your duties for brevity ſake you ſhall finde ſpecified in that copy of your Order. Kiſs the book.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I'le ſwear to them whatſoever they be.
So, now I am a Blade, and of a better Rowe then thoſe of Tytere tu, or Oatmeal hoe, and ſo an health to our Fraternity, and in chief to our Noble Captain Driblow.

sp.speaker: Nick. Ant.
sp.p: Agreed, Agreed.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Now are you to practiſe or exerciſe your qua|lity on the next you meet that is not of the Brother|hood.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Are you one of the Brotherhood ſir, of the Philoblathici.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I had elſe loſt much ſir, I have paid all dues be|longing to it.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: So have I as I hope to gain honour by't 40 li. thick at leaſt; yet I have this left, pleaſe you command the half ſir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Another time, your reckoning is not yet paid perhaps.
sp.stage: [Clot. puts his money in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: 'Tis the firſt money of mine that was refuſ'd ſince my coming to Town. I ſhall ſave infinitely.
I ſee now that I am ſworn. How would I ſwear to get by it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Take heed of that, Come hither ſon.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: How have you ſcrewed this youth up into this humour, that was ſuch a dry miſerable Clown but two dayes ſince.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The old way, by watching of him, and keep|ing him high-flown a mattet of fourty eight houres to|gether.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Men are apt to beleeve ſtrange fancies in their liquour, and to entertain new opinions.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I have faſtned three or foure cups upon my preciſe brother. I would 'twere as many pottles, ſo it would convert him into the right way of good fel|lowſhip.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vvould vve could ſee him, to try vvhat good vve could do upon him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Perhaps vve might convert him.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He's above ſtill vvith the old men. I ſtole from him, but to ſee if your Italick Myſtreſſe vvere come yet. Your Madam.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, ſhe comes anon; but is my affliction a|bove ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thy father? yes

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Ptithee do not call him my father leſs he took better courſes.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And ſo is thy Siſter; the little Rogue looks ſo ſqueamiſhly on me, and I on her, as we had never ſeen before; but the fooliſh Ape out of a preſent affecti|on ſhe has taken to my Siſter, has diſcovered to her the whole diſcourſe of our love, and my familiarity with thee, which were enough to ſpoile all, if it were diſcovered to the old folkes, befote my cards were play'd.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well, remember Mr. Mihil, you have pro|miſed me half, if the old dogged fellow give her all, and you marry her.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thou canſt not doubt me.

sp.speaker: Nick
sp.p: You know I can ſpoile all when I liſt, but to ſhew my countenance in your cauſe.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Such is your vertue, Sir. Well, I'le up to 'em again before I be miſt; and when they part, I am for you again.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have given you all the rudimenrs, and my moſt fatherly advices withal.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And the laſt is that I ſhould not ſwear, how make you that good? I thought now I was ſworne into this Brotherhood, I might have ſworne what, and as much as I would.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That's moſt unneceſſary, for look you ſon, the beſt, and even the leudeſt of my ſons do forbear it, not out of conſcience, but for very good ends; and in ſtead of an Oath furniſh the mouth with ſome af|fected Proteſtation. As I am honeſt, it is ſo. I am no honeſt man if it be not. Ud take me, if I lie to you. Nev'rgo, nev'rſtirre, l vow, and ſuch like.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Or never credit me or let me never be truſted.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: O take heed of that, that may be ſpoken in ſo ill an houre, that you may run out of reputati|on, and never be truſted indeed; the other will gaine you credit, and bring you into good and civil eſtimati|on with your Hoſteſſes; and make 'em terme you a faire conditioned Gentleman if he had it; and truly I never heard worſe word come out of his mouth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Nev'r-go, nev'r-ſtir, I vow. l'le have, I vow then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vow, but you ſhall not, that's mine.

sp.speaker: Clot
sp.p: Cann't you lend it me now and then brother? I'le have, I ſwear then, and come as nigh ſwearing as I can.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I ſwear but you muſt not, that's mine you know.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I proteſt then, I'le have I proteſt, that's a Ci|ty-word, and beſt to cozen with.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Come boyes, fall to ſome practice, Let me ſee about at the new French balls, ſprung out of the old Engliſh vapours

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I proteſt come on. I'le make a third man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Whoſe man are you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Whoſe man is not to be asked, nor ſcarce whoſe ſubject, now he is of our Brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, by your favour he may ask.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ask no favour, ſir.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: That may be granted.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You can grant nothing in this kinde.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vow he may grant any thing of any kinde.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I ſwear, I neither can, nor will grant that.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: That, I proteſt, may bear exception in|deed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Exceptions amongſt us? nay, then I vow.—

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I ſwear.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And I proteſt—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Part faire my boyes; 'tis very well per|form'd; now drink a round to qualifie this bout.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed on all parts.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Look upon me ye Common-wealths men now, like a State-Surgeon, while I ſearch and try
sp.l: The ulcerous coare of foule enormitie.
Theſe are a parcel of thoſe venomous weeds,
That ranklie peſter this faire Garden-plot.
Whoſe boiſterous growth is ſuch, that I muſt uſe
More policie then ſtrength to reach their root,
And hoiſt them up at once.
This is my way to get within 'em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So, 'tis gone round.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I muſe theſe Mumpers come not.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Beſt ſend a boy.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Drawer, ha! where be thoſe Raſcalls? (Within) By and by.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Are you one of 'em, ſir?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I am one that has the favour of the houſe, ſir?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: To intrude into Gentlemens privacies? ha!

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: To ſeek a poor living and 't pleaſe you, by picking up the crums of your liberalitie, for the uſe of my rare qualities.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And what's your qualitie?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: It is to ſpeak or ſing ex tempore upon any Theame, that your fancie or the preſent occaſion ſhall adminiſter.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Can you drink before you lay your lips to't

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O my weak eye-ſight.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Or can you eate a cruſt without chawing, made of the Flower of Battoon.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O good Gentlemen, forbear, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The flower of Battoon. I proteſt a good jeſt, and 'twas mine own before I was aware, for he had the Maidenhead or firſt-blow of my Battoon. Nay, it ſhall down.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I will not yet deſiſt; but ſuffer private affli|ction with a Romane reſolution for the publike wel|fare, with full aſſurance that my fortitude ſhall at laſt get within 'em.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You are not ſatisfied, i● ſeems, you Raſcal, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Phew! beat not the poor fellow ſo.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Let me come to him again, and fleſh my ſelf upon him. I will not only fleſh my ſelf, but tire up|on him.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Enough, enough, good Gentlemen, you have beaten me enough of conſcience. Was ever good Pa|triot ſo rudely handled? but the end crowns all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Forbear him ſons. What canſt thou be, that canſt not be ſatisfied with beating? ſpeak, art a man or a Ghoſt?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I have been, Sir, a man, and of my hands, howe're misfortune humbles me under your man|hoods. But I have ſeen the face of warre, and ſerv'd in the Low-countreys, though I ſay't, on both ſides.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Then 'tis impoſſible this fellow can be beat out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Mick.
sp.p: We'll leave him in his qualiry for that con|ſtant vertue.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sure, 'tis Fenner or his Ghoſt. He was a ri|ming ſouldier. Look, do his eyes ſtand right?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: They had a diſh e'ne now, ſir.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Of ſack, 'tis true here, take another, and waſh the inſide of your Throat. And let us hear your pipes in their right tune.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Give me a Theam Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The praiſe of ſack. Sing the praiſe of ſack.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let it be of the Blade.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And the Battoon, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Do you call, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, I will have ſack.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: T'other quart of Canarie? you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Are your eares ſo quick? I vow, I'le dull 'em.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I ſay, a ſong of Sack.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I, let it be of Sack.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Now you pump, do you?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No, ſir, but think of a tune.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: If he can pump us up a ſpring of Sack, we'll keep him, and break half the Vintners in Town.
sp.stage: (Song. Now B. and Clot. askes Gabriel, Are you a b●other. They fall in the burthen.)

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, well-ſaid.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ſwear, 'twas well.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I proteſt the beſt that I have heard in this kind. I wonder at his ability. I prithee, art not ac|quainted with my two Poetical Drury-lane Writers? the Cobler and the Tapſter.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No ſir, not I, I work not their way. What I do is ex tempore after the Theme given.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: But they run quite before you. Their Works are in print ſometimes▪ and ready to be ſung about ſtreets, of men that are hang'd before they come to the Gallowes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But did not Mihil ſay he would come again.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I marvel at his ſtay.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I, and the Mumpers, when come they? I long to ſee the Siſters, now I am a brother ſworn and entred.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O here comes news. How now pig?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: You muſt all preſentlie to the Paris Tavern.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Muſt? at whoſe ſuit!

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Mr. Mihil bade me tell you ſo.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is he gone from hence?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: He is, and all his gone and diſperſed.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Then the old Jew my father's gone.

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Only there's one delicate demure Gentleman with Mr. Mihil. travell'd along with him towards Pa|ris. I believe he meanes to make a mouth of him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O, 'tis his preciſe brother. But vvhere's thy Myſtreſſe, and Madama Damaris? that they come not.

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: They deſire to meet you there too, 'tis more private.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Avvay vve'll follovv thee.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Pig, hovv does thy father Hog, the Turkie Merchant?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: I am in haſte, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why Turkie Merchant?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Becauſe he trades in nothing but Turkie commodities; Egges and Concubines; 'tvvere vvell to geld him, and ſend him to the Grand Seignior, to vvait in his Seraglio.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Thou haſt ſuch a vvit in this Clotpoll of thine. The Reckoning Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Here, here, Sir; here's your bill.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let ſee the ſumme. What is't Drawer? 40. ſh. and 3. d. Si, your dinner, and what you had ſince, in all, ſir.

sp.speaker: Capt,
sp.p: 'Tis very reaſonable, Commend me to thy Maſter. Son Clotpoll pay't. It is your duty.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, for my Brotherſhip.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Boyes, I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: 40. ſh. for foure mens dinners, note that, yet he ſayes 'tis reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Good Captain, He was ever the faireſt Reckoner, though he has never the luck to pay any thing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fare you well, father.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: When we have further occaſion, we'll re|pair to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: At Bloomesbury. Father, I know.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Bloomsbury? good, I note it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sirrah, look to the ſecond Article of your Oath.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Againſt diſcovery of lodgings, haunts, or by-walks, I am warn'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Look that you be ſo.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 40. ſh. and 3. d. you'l bate the 3. d. will you not?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: We'll not much ſtand for that Sir, though our Maſter ſits at deare rent.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Give me your two peeces.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray let me ſee the bill before you pay it.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well, I can hold it then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Bread and beer, 1. ſh. 4. d. I do not think we four could eat 3. d. of bread, and for my part, I drank but two glaſſes of beer.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And I but one, Ivow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And my father and I but one betwixt us, I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Ha' you no men below?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Below the earth doeſt mean? I am ſure we have none above-ground.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I know not, Gentlemen, there's ſo much reckon'd at the bar, and you pleaſe you may ſee it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, an't be at the bar, it ſtands for Law. Well, wine 5 ſh. 9. d. I think we had no leſſe. A Shoulder of Mutton ſtuff't with Oyſters 8. ſh. that coſt your Maſter very near ten groats, a brace of Par|tridge 5. ſh. a couple of Cocks 4. ſh. 6. d. a dozen of Larks 20. d. Anchovis 6. ſh. I ſwear but a Sawcer full.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I'le be ſworne they are ſo much reckon'd in the Kitch●n.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All's law, I tell you, all's law in Tavernes. But I hope there will be a law for you one o'theſe dayes. Then is their Fruit and Cheeſe, Tobaccho, Fire, and I know not what, is't right caſt.

sp.speaker: Cock.
