sp.p: There is more hope of that young man, then of all the reſt, indeed it is a ſore abuſe, another verie weed in the city. I do note that alſo.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Sirrah, before you have your money, fetch me a glaſſe of Beere. But canſt thou ſing this upon a|ny ſubject.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Any ſir, any, an't be till midnight.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: But you have ſtrange helps to your inventi|on. I did note the rolling o' th' eye, and rubbing your Brows ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: So did I, I proteſt, and therefore, I tell you what. If he can ſing ſuch another Song, and look ſtedfaſtly the while upon any thing, and hold his hands behind him. I'le give him half a crown; if not, he ſhall ha' nothing for tother.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Agreed Gentlemen, give me your Theme.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You ſhall give it him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And withal, watch him if he ſtir hand or eye, eſpecially the eye.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I will I proteſt, and ſet mine eye againſt his, that he ſhall not twink, but I'le perceive it, and lay him o're the pare.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Well Sir, your Theme.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: In praiſe of the Battoon, and if you miſſe it you ſhall be ſure on't.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: You'll help me with the burthen, Gentle|men.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, yes, for the more grace of the Song.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take you no care for that. Set your eyes and begin.

lg.l: To prove the Battoon the moſt noble to be.
Of all other weapons obſerve his degree,
In Field to be Leader of all other Armes,
To conqueſt and honour, through hazard and harms.
The Gallant and Peaſant, the Lord and the Lowne.
Muſt move by the motion of the Leaders Battoon.
The Pike and the Halbert are ſubject to it.
The Enſigne, the Partizan, all muſt ſubmit,
To advance, or retire, fall back, or come on.
As they are directed by the Leaders Battoon.
Then it is to the Souldier the greateſt Renown,
To purchaſe by ſervice to bear the Battoon.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Marry, and take it Sir, why do you ſtare a|bout? though you have broke Covenant, I have not.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Where be the Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Ha! they are not gone, I hope, where be my brothers Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Gone ſir, and have ſent me to you for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I proteſt you jeſt, do you not? I gave 'em the full ſumme, and all the money I had, I proteſt, I ſwear, I vow, now they are not here, I may make bold with their words. They have my money, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: If you have no money, pray leave a pawne, ſir.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take him there, put him in a cage, and let him ſing it out.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: We know him not, ſir.

sp.speaker: Clat.
sp.p: No? he ſaid he had the favour of the houſe to ſing to Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I feare I ſhall be diſcovered, ſir, I can give your worſhip credit for a peece till you come to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Proteſt, thou art generous; nay, I know where to finde'em; and thou ſhalt go with me to 'em, we will not part now, wee'll ſhoune 'em. I vow, (the words out) here, I'le leave my ſword for t'other peece.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Your ſword will not ſerve, ſir, I doubt.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take my coat too, a friend and a Battoon is better then a coat and a ſword at all times.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.l: I am glad my feare is over. And after all my ſufferings, if at laſt
Cock braine crow not theſe roaring Lions down,
Let him be balladed about the Town.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let me now bid you welcome to my fathers houſe, where till your own be fitted, though my father keep too private a family to expreſſe large entertain|ment, yet I hope at worſt you ſhall ha' convenient lodging.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Indeed, I am glad that my father yielded to your fathers friendly requeſt in it; and the more, in regard he is ſo hard to be entreated to any thing; but eſpecially for your ſocieties ſake, ſweet Siſter. In|deed I'le call you Siſter alwayes, and I hope you ſhall be ſhortly in my brother Mihils right.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have laid open my heart to you, which in|deed is his, but your father, I feare, will never be wonne.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Why you would not have him too, Siſter, would you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: His conſent I would, and my fathers, I hope, would eaſily be wrought. You ſaw he was willing your other brother ſhould have me at the firſt ſight, meerly for his reſervedneſſe, and Mihil methought carried himſelf as civil to day as he; I mean, as ci|villy for a Gentleman, that ſhould not look like one fathers of the Dutch Church at five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: He was put to't to day. The noiſe of the Tavern had almoſt wrought his zeale in●o fury, it is ſcarce out of my head yet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But you were about to tell me how he firſt fell into this veine, this vanity indeed.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I'le tell you now, and in that ſomething worth your obſervation.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I will obſerve you.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
My father has an humour, not to like any thing at firſt, nor accept beſt courteſies of friends,
though preſently he findes 'em moſt commodious to him; things that he knows not how to be without, and oftentimes deſires with the ſame breath the things he viliſied, and ſcorn'd them the laſt ſyllable he ſpake before. You ſaw when your father offered him the uſe of his houſe here, till his own be furniſhed, he cried, hah ● are all the houſes in the Town yours Sir; and yet preſently entreated for't, and thanked him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That ſhews the beſt nature, they ſay.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But that is ſeldome attended by the beſt fortune. Nay, in us, I mean, his children, he will like nothing, no, not thoſe actions which he him|ſelf cannot deny are vertuous; he will croſſe us in all we do, as if there were no other way to ſhew his power over our obedience.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſtrange fatherly care.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now, note the puniſhment that followes it. There's not a chil●e he has, ●hough we all know what we do, that make any conſcience of croſſing him, we have ſo much of his good nature in us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And that's as odde a duty in children.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I muſt confeſſe it is a ſtubbornneſſe.

Yet for the moſt part we do nothing, but that which moſt Parents would allow in their children: and now for my brother Gabriel, with whom I muſt bring in the ſtory of another Kinſwoman of ours, my father had at home with us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Nay, mark, I pray you, as I would entreat an Auditorie, if I now were a Poet to mark the Plot, and ſeveral points of my play, that they might not ſay when 'tis done, they underſtood not this or that, or how ſuch a part came in or went out, becauſe they did not obſerve the paſſages.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well on, I pray.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
My brother Gabriel, when he was a boy, nay,
till within theſe two yeares, vvas the wildeſt unta|med thing that the countrey could poſſibly hold.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So he is ſtill for ought I know, for I think no man of his Religion in his wits.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I mean in outvvard converſation, he vvas the Ring-leader of all the youthful Frie, to Faires, to Wakes, to May-games, footbal-matches, any thing that had but noiſe and tumult in it; then he was Captain of the young train-band, and exerciſed the youth of tvventy pariſhes in martial diſcipline. O he did love to imitate a ſouldier the beſt,—and ſo in every thing, that there vvas not an handſom maid in an whole County could be quiet for him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He may be good at that ſport ſtill, for there is almoſt none of his ſect holds any other game lavvful.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yet did he bear the civilleſt aud the beſt or|dered affection to our Kinſvvoman I ſpake of.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, I remember.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: So loving to her perſon, ſo tender of her ho|nour that nothing but too near affinity of blood could have kept them aſunder.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And ſhe did love him as vvell!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: O dearly, vertuouſly vvell; but my father fearing vvhat youth in heat of blood might do, re|moves my brother Gabriel from home into the ſer|vice of a Reverend Biſhop to follovv good ex|amples.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But he learned not to be a Puritane there I hope.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
You ſhall hear, Siſter, ſoon after came a Gal|lant into the countrey from London here, and as vve after found, a Citizens ſonne, though he ſhevved like a Lord there. Briefly, he grevv acquainted vvith my brother Mihil. Then vvoo'd and vvonne my
Couſin ſo ſecretly, my father never ſuſpected, nor he nor I e're knevv vvhoſe ſon he vvas, nor of vvhat occupation my old lord his father vvas; but he pro|miſ'd her marriage, clap't her, you may gueſſe vvhere, and ſo like the ſlippery Trojan left her.

sp.speaker: Euc.
sp.p: O divelliſh Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And fooliſh creature, ſhe vvho ſoon repented it, and vvith her ſhame is fled to vvhat part of the vvorld vve knovv not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: In truth 'tis pitiful, that villain vvould be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Novv upon this, my poor brother that lov'd her ſo, fell into diſcontent, forſook his lord, and vvould have left the Land, but that he vvas prevented and brought home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And ever ſince he has been thus religious.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Thus obſtinate, for I think verily he does it but to croſſe my father, for ſending him out of the vvay vvhen the miſchief vvas done.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I vvill not then beleeve 'tis Religion in any of the gang of 'em, but meer vvilful affectation. But vvhy, or vvherein do you or Mihil. croſſe your fa|ther.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I tell you Siſter vve muſt. He is ſo croſſe him|ſelf, that vve ſhall never get any thing of him that we deſire, but by deſiring the contrary.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why then do you deſire him to get you an hus|band?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Becauſe he ſhould get me none. O Siſter, both he and Mr. Cockbrayne, can vviſh novv that I had had his ſon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There's another youth novv gone on love's pilgrimage, e're ſince your father croſthim in your love not to be heard of.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Huſh! the old men.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: In good truth ſir, I am taken with your con|verſation. I like it now exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I'm glad it pleaſes you.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: 'Tis very faire and friendly, I finde we ſhall accord.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I am glad I have it for you Sir, I pray, make bold with it.

sp.speaker: Ro●k.
sp.p: Then pray ſir, let me urge my motion a little further to you.

sp.speaker: Croſ,
sp.p: What is't? you cannot utter it ſo eaſily as I ſhall grant it, out with it man.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: That you will be pleaſed to accept my daugh|ter for either of your ſons, your youngeſt if you pleaſe, now I have ſeen him, I'le give him with her preſently, either in hand a thouſand pound, and five hundred pound a childe as faſt as he can get 'em. And all I ſhall die ſeiz'd of.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What a Dogbolt is this to think that I ſhould get a childe for him.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I hope you do think well on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray love he does. I hope ſo too.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I mark his Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I could finde in my heart to ask his good-will my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And that were a ſure way to go without it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: How ſay you, ſir, is't a match?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I will not ſtay a minute in thy houſe, though I lie in the ſtreet for●t.
Huswife, I'le ſort you with f●tter companions, Come, follow me quickly.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: H●aven bleſſe me and my childe too from matching with ſuch a diſpoſition.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Truly, ſir, I long'd to be out o th' houſe be|fore.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Before you came in it did you not? ha!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Theſe new walls do ſo ſtink of the lime me|thinks.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Marry fough, Gooddie Foyſt.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: There can be no healthie dwelling in 'em this twelve-moneth yet.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Are you ſo tender bodied?

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Even pleaſe your ſelves then where you can like better, and you ſhall pleaſe me.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Why you will not thruſt me out of your houſe, will you? ha!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: There's no ſuch haſte, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Indeed there is not, nor will I out for all your haſte neither. I'le have look to my bargain.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: With all my heart, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: But no more of your idle motions, if you love your eaſe in your houſe, your ●●n here.
Here's a letter, ſir, from Mr. Cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Is the earer paid, or give him that an't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Some body has anger'd him, and I muſt ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I ſent you to ſeek my ſons, good ſir, have you found 'em? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I cannot finde 'em ſir. They went out of the Tavern together, they ſay, and I have been at Mr. Mihils chamber, and there they are not. I went to the Tavern again, and there they were not. ●hen I beat all the reſt o'th' buſhes, in this four eſt of foo es and mad men, and cannot finde em I, where e're they be.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
Sirrah, go finde em me where e're they be, a|ny where, or no where, finde 'em, and finde 'em
quickly; I'le finde 'em in your Cockſcombe elſe, d' ye ſee! and bring my ſons Sanctity home before it be dark, leſt he take up his lodging in a Church-porch; and charge Mr. Mihil that he come not to me till I ſend for him. Here's danger i'th' houſe. There was a match-motion indeed.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Good ſir, either like my houſe well, or be pleaſ'd to pleaſe your ſelf with ſome better.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Pray Sir, be quiet in your houſe, leſt I ſend you out of it to ſeek another. Let me ſee my cham|ber.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: He muſt have his way, I ſee.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Bettie, Frank, with ſwords drawn make faſt the doors.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.l: NAy, you perpetual Puſſe, I'le fetch him out of the very bowels of thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He never came ſo deep himſelf yet with all that he could do, and I ſcorne the threatning of a She Marmaſet.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: (Within) why Bettie, Frank, you mankinde Carions you. I vow, open the door, will you both kill one another, and cozen the Hangman of his fees?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Thou hadſt been better have bit off the dugs of thy Damme, thou pin-buttock Jade thou, than have ſnapt a bit of mine from me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Here's that ſhall ſtay your ſtomack better then the bit you ſnarle for. Thou greedy Brach thou.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: (Within) why wenches, are ye wild? break open the doores.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: That I could ſplit that divelliſh tongue of thine!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I have as good a ſpight at as ill a member about thee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Hold, what's the devil in ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Are ye ſo ſharp-ſet ye Amazonian Trulls?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Let me but make one paſſe at her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pray let me go, and let her come.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Can no blunter tooles then theſe ſerve to take down your furies?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Let me come but within nailes reach of het.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let me but try the ſtrength of my teeth upon her.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: As Hector 'twixt the hoſts of Greece and Troy,
When Paris and the Spartane King ſhould end
Their nine yeares warres, held up his brazen lance.
In ſignal, that both Armies ſhould ſurceaſe,
And hear him ſpeak. So let me crave your audience.
Dear Bettie be adviſ'd, and Frank, forbear
Thy thirſt of Siſters blood. Whileſt I rip up
The folly of your ſtrife. Your caſes both
Have been laid open to me. You contend
For love of a lewd Citizen, that ſleights,
Nay more, diſdaines, nay more, deſies you both.
Tony can tell, Mun Clotpoll alſo knows
The words he ſpake, that you were both poor whores,
Not poor alone, but foule infectious harlots.
And that he wears your mark with pain and ſorrow,
Hopeleſſe to claw them off. With conſtant purpoſe
Never to ſee you more, unleſſe to greet.
Your bumpin buttocks with revengeful feet.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Did he ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And muſt we two fall out for ſuch a ſlander|ous Villain?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, agree, agree.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Buſſe and be friends. Buſſe, or I'le baſte ye both, I vow.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Come Siſter we'll be in for ever now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: For my part, Siſter, ſure I was not out with you.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: But did he ſay he would kick us?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lo here, the man that dares it not deny.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: But do ye hear, Gentlemen. I hope you will uſe me kindlier then ſo.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Than how, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Then to win all my money, and leave me at ſtake for the reckoning. Pray do you pay the Drawer for me, though I pay it you again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What is it Drawer?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The Gentlewomen and he had 14. ſh. in before you came.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 'Tis a plain caſe, your cloak muſt anſwer it at the bar, Sir. Drawer, away with it.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Nay, but Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, do but look after it, till we be gone, and theſe ſhall claw thine eyes out.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well ſir, I hope this quarter will not be al|wayes lawleſſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do you grumble? Mr. C●ffeleſſe.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow you ſhall have cu●●es.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Yes, that you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Cuts and ſlaſhes too before we part, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You will not murder me, will you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Damoſels forbear; and you, forbear your noiſe. I vow, I'le ſlit your wiſtle elſe. You ſhall give him due correction civilly, and we will make him take it civilly. Sit you down Sir.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: What will you do with me?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, mum.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O, are ye here! was it a brotherly trick do ye think, to leave me to pay one reckoning twice? or did I think never to be made a mouth more, after I had paid my ſwearing dinner, and am I now a greater mouth then e're I was?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Mum, hold your tongue ſtill in your mouth, leſt I halifax it with your teeth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Halifax my tongue. And liſten to a buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Do yon know this man?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, the City mouth we had tother night.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Theſe are the Siſters that his laviſh tongue ſo lewdly did deprave.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I cry them heartily mercy Are you of the ſweet Siſterhood? I hope to know you all, all the pretty Mumpers in the berrie here, before I have done. 'Tis true, I proteſt, he ſpake words of you, that ſuch fleſh and blood could not bear. He could not have ſpoken worſe of mutton of a groat a quarter.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: And were we ſo fond to fight for him?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But now we'll both be revenged upon the fleſh of him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pray let me ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, they ſhall beat you firſt. And mark me well. Do thou but ſtir an hand or foot, or raiſe a voice that may be heard to the next room, well cut thy weaſand. Now wenches take your courſe.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Nay, you ſlave, we'll mark you for a Sheep|biter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We'll teach you how to ſcandalize.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Have I given you that you cannot claw off, you Mungrel.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Rare, I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: There, there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We'll claw thine eares off rather.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O brave.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O out-rage, moſt inſufferable, all this goes into my black book.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: To him Bettie, at him Frank; there whores, there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fie, fie, forbear, enough, too much in con|ſcience.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: That young man has ſome pity yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ſwear you ſhall no more.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Alas, good Gentlemen, it is enough.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, do you prate? you ſhall have as much. Come, take the Chaire, Sir, the breeches ſhall bait him too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O good Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, they ſhall. To him and claw him, I'le clapperclaw your ſides elſe

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O me! what mean you?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Heyday! his beard comes off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And his head too What rotten ſcab is this?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I proteſt, they have pulled my pieced brother in pieces here.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, ſome diſguiz'd villain, and but for do|ing the State ſo good ſervice, we would hang him pre|ſently without examination.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know him. And you ſhall not touch him. Beſt is, he knows nor me. Good Heaven, what Brain|trick has poſſeſt him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, what canſt thou be?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, 'tis an honeſt fellow, that is only a|ſham'd to run ſo baſe a courſe for his living in his own face. Poor man, I warrant his feare threatens his breeches ſhrewdly. But let's away, and quickly, our ſtay is dangerous. Come, we forgot Mich. Croſwil and the wenches.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Come all away then, Sirrah, thank this Gentleman, and pray for him at the end of your Songs hereafter.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Farewel, friend Peece. I'le know you better now, before you have't again.
sp.stage: Ex. omnes but Cock. and Cit.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What monſters in mankinde? what hell-hounds are they? only as Ovid feign'd among the Getes. A friend at need, I with a friend was bleſt, Whom I may gratifie, and plague the reſt. How is it with you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: O, I am very ſore.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Indeed you are ſorely handled. This may warne you out of ſuch caterwaling company. You look like one more civil. And in hope you will be ſo, I'le bring you to a Barber.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Alas, my Cloke.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I'le help you to that too, ſo you with me, Will in an honeſt plot Aſſiſtant be.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: O Sir, in any thing, and thank you too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: A Paris ill ya ben veni- Here's no buſh at this door, but good wine rides poſt upon't, I mean, the ſign-poſt. Boy, get you down, and if Nick Rooksbill, or any of his company ask for me, bring 'em up, d'ye hear.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will, I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You are welcome to Paris brother Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is nevertheleſſe a Tavern, brother Mihil, and you promiſed and covenanted with me at the laſt houſe of noiſe and noiſomneſſe, that you would not lead me to any more Tavernes.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Lead you brother? men uſe to be led from Tavernes ſometimes. You ſaw I did not lead you nor bring you to any that was more a Tavern then the laſt, nor ſo much neither; for here is no Buſh you ſaw.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: 'Twas that betrayed and entrapped me: but let us yet forſake it.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray let us drink firſt brother. By your leave here's to you.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: One glaſſe-full more is the moſt that I can bear. My head is very full, and laboureth with that I have had already.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: There Sir, I'le undertake one good fellow, that has but juſt as much Religion as will ſerve an honeſt mans turne, will bear more wine then ten of theſe gid|dy-braind Puritanes, their heads are ſo full of whim|ſeys.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: 'Tis mighty headie, mighty headie, and truly I cannot but think that the over much abuſe of theſe out-landiſh liquors, have bred ſo many errours in the Romiſh Church.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Indeed brother, there is too much abuſe made of ſuch good creatures. Wine in it ſelf is good, you will grant, though the exceſſe be nought; and Ta|vernes are not contemptible, ſo the company be good.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is moſt true, we finde that holy men have gone to Tavernes, and made good uſe of 'em upon their Peregrinations.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
And cannot men be content to take now and
then a cup, and diſcourſe of good things by the way. As thus. Brother, here's a remembrance (if ſhe be li|ving, and have not loſt her honour) to our Couſin Dore as.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O that kinſwoman of ours. She was the dear|eſt loſſe that e're fell from our houſe.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Pledge her, good brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I do—

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope 'twill maudlenize him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: But have you never ſeen that miſcreant that wrong'd her, ſince he did that ſame, they ſay you knew him.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Alas, ſuppoſe I had, what could be done? ſhe's loſt we ſee. What good could ſhe receive by any courſe againſt him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It had been good to have humbled him, though into the knowledge of his Tranſ●reſſion. And of himſelf for his ſoules good, either by courſe of Law, or elſe in caſe of neceſſity, where the Law promiſeth no releefe, by your own right hand you might have ſmote him, ſmote him with great force, yea, ſmote him unto the earth, until he had prayed that the evil might be taken from him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: This is their way of loving enemies, to bear 'em into goodneſſe. Well, brother, I may meet with him again, and then I know what to do. If he knew him as I do now, what a religious combate were here like to be at Nicks coming.
Sir, here's a Gentlewoman asks for Mr. Rooks|bill.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: The travell'd Gallant, is't not.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes ſir, and the old black party, her Land lady with her. But they ask for no body but him, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Say he is here by all meanes, and bring 'em up.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Women! pray brother lets avoid the place, let us flie it. What ſhould we do with women in a Ta|vern?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: No harme aſſure your ſelfe, cannot we go|vern ourſelves?
sp.stage: Enter Dorcas and Madge, and ſtart back.

sp.speaker: Nay,
sp.p: Lady, ſtay, he will be here preſently, that you look for.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will not glance an eye toward tempta|tion.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I am amaz'd ſure, I have ſeen this face, howe're your habit and the courſe of time may give't another ſeeming.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Good Angels, help my thoughts and memo|ry. It is my Kinſman Mihil. What's the other that hides his face, ſo?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Do you turn away?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: It is my Couſin Gabriel, ſtrangely altered.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Come hither you. I●le make a little bold with you. Thou that haſt been a concealer of more ſins in womens actions, then thou haſt grizled hairs.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Sure I will ſpeak to him, he alwayes lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Reveale a truth to me on my demand, now inſtanrly, without premeditation. I'le cut thy tongue out elſe.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What's here to do? do you think I am a devil? that you make ſuch conjurations over me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I think thou art as true a ſervant of his as any Bawd can be. But he now if thou dareſt. How long have you known that Gentlewoman? and what do you know by her?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Here's a ſtirre about nothing. I know no|thing by her, not ●. Nor whether ſhe has any thing or nothing, that a woman ſhould have by the re|port of knowledge of man, woman or beaſt, not I. She came to me but this morning, with a purpoſe to ſet me up in my new houſe as I hoped. But ſhe has taken a courſe to make it honeſtly ſpoken of already, to my utter undoing, but ſhe never comes within my doors again, as I hope to thrive by my Trade here|after.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Pray look upon me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Was ſhe ſo reſolutely bent, and ſo ſoon al|tered?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Upon the very firſt fight of the very firſt man that came into my houſe, the very firſt houre of my ſetting up in it.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: What man was that?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: A ſhame take him, your roaring friend, Nick. I think ſhe is enamoured of him, or of ſomething ſhe gueſſes he has; and would faine play the honeſt woman with him, that never played honeſt man with woman in his life.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: 'Tis ſhe, and 'tis moſt wonderful.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: If you knew who I were, you would not be ſo ſtrange to me.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And here ſhe comes me a hunting after him, like a fondling, whileſt halfe a dozen peeces might ha' been gotten at home by this time, aud ſhe have had the halfes of it in her purſe by this time; if ſhe would have done, as I thought, ſhe would have done by this time.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Alas, poor Howlet.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I ſent whooping after the beſt gueſt that haunt my houſe, to have taken the firſt fruits of her converſation, and ſhe would not ſee a man of 'em, to my undoing.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well leave thy hooting, Madge, and hold thy peace. thou ſhalt get by it.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhall get a good name ſhortly, and this geare hold, and turn begger, I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pray ſir, but one word.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Speak to her, brother, 'tis our Couſin Dor|cas.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Will you abuſe me too? is ſhe not loſt?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And will not you give her leave to be found again? his wine and her ſudden apprehenſion works on him at once. Couſin, I'le ſpeak to you, though I confeſſe the miracle of our meeting thus ama|zes me.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: O Couſins both. As ye are Gentlemen, and of that noble ſtock, whoſe meer remembrance, when he was given up, and at the brink of deſperate folly, ſtroke that reverend fear into my ſoul, that hath pre|ſerv'd my honour from further falling. Lend me now your aide, to vindicate that honour by that man, that threw me in the way of loſſe and ruine.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: All ſhall be well, good Couſin, you ſhall have both hands and hearts to re-eſtate you in him. So that in fact you have not wrong'd that ho|nour, ſince he forſook you.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: On my ſoule I have not.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Infants then ſhall be pardoned. Brother ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: You were wont ſtill to be my loving'ſt Cou|ſin.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What a ſtrange dream has wine wrought in my head.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.l: I hope it will work out his ſuperfluous zeale.
And render him civil Chriſtian again.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It is no dream, good Couſin, you are awake,
And I, that Dorcas, for whom you have wiſh't

Affinity of blood might be diſpen●'d with. And you
to be my choice. So well you lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And will above my life affect you ſtill. But you muſt leave theſe gauds and prophane dreſ|ſings.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Bawds did he ſay? how comes he to know me troe?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.l: How came my Couſin Gabriel thus tran|ſlated.
Out of gay cloathes long haire, and lofty ſpirit,
Stout and brave action, manly carriage;
Into ſo ſtrict a Reformation?
Where is the martial humour he was wont ſo to affect.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: His purity and your diſgrace fell on you both about a time, I faith.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Do you ſwear by your FAITH?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He's falling back again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Some more wine. You will drink with our
Couſin, brother, will you not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What wine is't, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes, in a cup of ſincere love.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What other wine you pleaſe, Gentlemen, we have none ſuch i●th' houſe.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Of the ſame we had, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Call not for wine for us, Couſin.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Aſſuredly, we are no prophane wine-bibbers, not we.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Modeſt, and well-ſpoken verily, ſhe ſhould be a Siſter or a Matron.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we'll all drink for the good o'th' houſe.
'Tis upon putting down, they ſay, and more o'th neighbours. But Couſin, he knew you not to day.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, nor dreams of me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And the old one knowes nothing, does ſhe.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: No, by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: She can bewray nothing then. My brother knows not him. I only do for his faire Siſters fake, of which you may hear more hereafter; in the mean, bear your ſelfe faire and free, as if you knew him not, and I'le work him to your end, never fear it.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: You are a noble Spokeſman.
sp.stage: [Bawd and Gabriel confer devoutly the while.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Truly, you ſpeak moſt edifyingly.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well-ſaid, give it to my brother. Drink to our Couſin, Brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will, and to that vertuous Matron, whoſe care of her, I hope, tends unto good edification.—Truly the wine is good, and I was ſomething thirſty.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Beſt drink again then, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will follow your motherly advice.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: 'Twill work, anon, I hope.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And you have travell'd Couſin. I may ſup|poſe you brought this well-diſpoſed Gentlewoman from Amſterdam with you. And this unto your wel|come, hoping I ſhall be informed by you how the two zealous brethren thrive there? that broke in St. Hellens.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Of that or any thing ſir, pray drink again, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You Jade you, hold your tongue.
sp.stage: Enter Nick, Anthony, Clotpoll, Bettie, Frank.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O, are ye here Gallants! I made all the haſte I co●●●, but was ſtayed, I vow, by the braveſt ſport, baiting of a fellow or two with our Puſſe-cats here. I could e'ne ſind in my heart to marry 'em both for their valours.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Thoſe words are daggers.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I pray diſſemble your paſſion.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: What? are you acquainted already?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee ſhe was a brave Ma|dona?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: How long have you had acquaintance with her, Nick?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Never ſaw her before this morning, I, ſtand|ing upon her Belconee.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Truly Couſin, I think 'twas you that I ſaw to day too, ſtanding upon a Bellconee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: You ſpell very modeſtly, ſir. Your brother
I take it. But did you call her Couſin, ſir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes ſir, ſhe is my Couſin.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: 'Twill out too ſoon. Why Nick, thou know|eſt theſe kinde of creatures call and are called Cou|ſins commonly.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, in their tribe. But I thought he had been too holy for them. But Dammy—

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O fearfully prophane!

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You ſaid you had a ſtorie to relate, of dire misfortune. and of unquoth hearing. I come to hear your ſtory, what ſtop you your eares at? ſir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I dare not ſpeak it but in thy reproof. Thou ſweareſt Gee o Dee, Dee a●m thee, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow thou lieſt, I call'd her Dammy, be|cauſe her name is Damyris,

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I ſay thou lieſt, her name is Dorcas, which was the name of an holy woman.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Shall we have things and things? I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: This vvill ſpoil all. Brother, I pray for|bear.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I may not forbear, I am moved for to ſmite him; yea, vvith often ſtripes to ſmite him; my zeal|ous wrath is kindled, and he ſhall flie before me.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Let me entreat you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Bet. Frank.
sp.p: What furie's this?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Great Damboys ſhrink, and give a little ground.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will purſue him in mine indignation.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O me!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And beat him into Potſheards.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Now he has bang'd the Pitcher, he may do any thing.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray, brother, be perſwaded.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A brother to be ſo controuled?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You ſir, put up your Steel-ſtick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I deſire but to know firſt, if he be a bro|ther.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes marry is he, ſir.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Sir, I am ſatisfied. So let him live.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to ask you, do theſe men take part with the brethren?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, and are brothers a little diſguiz'd, but for ſome ends.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Some State-occaſions.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Meer Intelligencers, to collect up ſuch and ſuch obſervations, for a great Separatiſt that is now writing a book againſt playing at Barlibreak, moulding of Cocklebread, and ſuch like prophane exerciſes.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Truly ſuch exerciſes are prophane exerciſes, that bear the denomination of good things ordained for mans uſe, as Barley, Cockles, and Bread are ſuch things to be made ſports and play-games? I pray you let me ſee theſe brethren again, to make my atone|ment with them. And are thoſe Siſters too, that were wi●h them?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
O, moſt notorious ones, and are as equally diſguiz'd to be as rank Spies as the other. S'lid man, and they ſhould be taken for ſuch as they are, they would be cut off preſently. They came in this
mad humour to be merry with you for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Pray let 'em come again, I ſhall not be well until I have rendred ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You muſt do as they do then, or they will think you are a Spie upon them.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will be as merry as they, let wine be given unto us.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: More wine, Boy, and bid 'em all come in.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas, Couſin, let him drink no more.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Couſin, it ſhall be for his good and yours, as I will order it.
sp.stage: Enter Nick. Anthonie, Clotpoll, Bettie, Frank, Drawer with wine

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: All welcome, not any repetition, but begin a new

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will begin it, two glaſſes: it ſhall be a faith|ful Salutation to all the Brothers and Siſters of—

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The Blade and the Scabberd.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: It ſhall go round.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'le ſwear you do not well to let him drink ſo.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well ſaid civil Roarer.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Let it go round, go to, you are a wag. I know what you mean by the Blade and the Scabberd.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Who could have thought this had been ſuch a brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Nay, who could have thought you had been of the brethren.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Brethren ſir, we are the Brothers.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yea, the diſguiz'd ones.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: How? diſguiz'd ones?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
Do not croſſe him again. If thou doeſt, and I do not maul thee. Yes, brother, theſe are vertu|ous
men howe're they ſeeeme.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, I have ſo much vertue as to rebuke thee for lying. But we are brethren, ſir, and as fa|ctious as you, though we differ in the Grounds; for you, ſir, defie Orders, and ſo do we; you of the Church, we of the Civil Magiſtrate; many of us ſpeak i'th' noſe, as you do; you out of humility of ſpirit, we by the wantonneſſe of the fleſh; now in de|votion we go beyond you, for you will not kneel to a ghoſtly father, and we do to a carnal Myſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le ſtop your mouth, you ſaid you came to be merry.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, I vow, and brought Fidlers along, but they muſt play i'th' next room, for here's one breaks all the Fiddles that come in his reach. Come fir, will you drink, dance, and do as we do?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I'le drink, I'le dance, I'le kiſſe, or do any thing, any living thing with any of you that is Bro|ther or Siſter. Sweet-heart let me feel thy Co|ney.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.l: I now he's in. Play Fidlers. Dance.
All bravely performed, admirably well done, &c.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, thou art a brother after my own heart.

sp.speaker: Women.
sp.p: We cannot commend you enough, ſir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: This done in civil fort among our ſelves, I hope, will prove no ſcandal to a brother.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 'Twill prove an honour to our faction.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I thirſt to do it honour.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Give him ſome wine, he thirſts.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Thou little dapper thing, thou, hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou ſeeſt he can ſcarce ſtand.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: No, my religious brethren, no more wine.
Enough's a feaſt, and little doth ſuffice.
sp.p:
I thirſt to do ſome honour to our cauſe. To lead
forth legions to fight a battel 'gainſt our. malignant adverſaries.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Brave.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Such an employment now would make me famous, for my ſufficiency of Att in Armes.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, this man has hidden things in him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He has as brave a warlike ſpirit, man, before his preciſe humour tainted it, as ever breath'd in Hector.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow then, a good orderly diet of nothing but ſack for a week together, would revive it in him, and bring it to good again.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I hope, 'tis done already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How do you, ſit?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I feare ſome Jeſuitical fumes have invaded my Brain pan. All me thinks goes whirley, whir|ley, whirley.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Beſt lie down upon a bed. Drawer!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Souldiers muſt not be curious. A Bench or a|ny thing.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The Gentleman may have a bed here, an't pleaſe you. But ſir, there's an old angry Gentleman below, that asks for you, and by all deſcription for that mortified Gentleman. And will by all meanes preſſe into your room here.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: It is my father.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: O me! What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: M●d. Bet. Fran.
sp.p: We ſhall be all clap't up.

sp.speaker: M●.
sp.p: Fear nothing, veile your face a little; Who is with him?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: No body but his old Servingman, that it ſeems diſcover'd you. You may put this Gentleman into this inner room, and keep the Key your ſelfe. I know not what charge he has about him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Admirable honeſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: And you may tell your father he is gone, for he is gone you ſee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow. a wit.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Now if you'll be civil, I may bring him up to you, if not, becauſe he is your father, we'll thruſt him out of doors, an't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Notable raſcal, well ſir, let him up. I know how to fit him.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: But this delays my buſineſſe, Couſin, and will, I fear, fruſtrate my hopes.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nor hinder any thing, I'le warrant thee, he's thine. Play Fidlers, t'other dance.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Will you! proteſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are not wilde?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Come Wenches, if he venture in his fathers ſight, ſhame take us and we bluſh.

sp.speaker: Croſſ. Belt.
sp.p: And I had not ſold all my land to live upon my money in Town here, out of danger or the Statute, I would give thee a Copihold for this diſ|covery.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I thank your worſhip, and truly 'tis a good|ly ſight, me thinks, an't pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: I'm glad it likes you. Heigh, excellent good again. Heigh, Heigh, what an happineſſe may fathers boaſt, that can bring their children up to this. (Dance ended) I cry ye mercy, Gentlemen all. Ha! I am ſo|ry I interrupted your ſerious private occaſions.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Would you ſpeak with any here, ſir?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: It is my father, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Tny father? hold thy peace; dar'ſt thou uſe thy father thus? to ſpend thy time thus! ha! Is this place fit for the ſon of a Geatleman of quality? ha! why doeſt not anſwer me, does this company ſort with thy reputation? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Sir, the company.—

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Hold thy peace, I ſay, or are theſe exerci|ſes allowable for a Gentleman, that ever ſaid or heard Grace at his fathers Table? anſwer me that.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: An't pleaſe you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Hold thy peace when I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The company, ſir, offends not you, I hope; you ſee the worſt of us.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: In good time, ſir, you are the diſtracted Gentlemen, I take it, that ask't him if he would moot to night? Is this your mooting? do you put caſes to your VVenches, or they to you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow thy father talkes too much.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Which are the better Lawyers? ha!

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But that you are his father, ſit, and an old man, and he an honeſt young Gentleman, and our friend, we would tell you.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: I thank you for him, yes truly, heartily; and for your good opinion of him, heartily. Pray keep him amongſt you while ye have him, for I'●e ha● no more to ſay to him, I. Is your Invectives againſt drinking, wenching, and the abomination of the times come to this? is this your ſpending of time more pretious then money? is it you that knows not what to do with money but to buy books; and were drawn with ſuch unwillingneſſe to a Tavern? ha! you ſhall graze upon Littletons Commons, or eat nothing but books, an't pleaſe you, for any exhibition thou e|ver get'ſt from me—And in that faith thou haſt loſt a father. Come ſir, you have brought me to a goodly ſight here; would any Villain but thy ſelfe have ſhewed his Maſter light to ſee ſo much woe! Thy Coxſcombe ſhall yet pay fot't.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O ſir, O.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: This was your trim ſight, was it?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: But well remembred. Pray where's your bro|ther? my ſon I would ſay; for I know no brother or father thou haſt. Where is Gabriel?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He is not here, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Did you not tell me, Sirrah, he was here?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I told you then too much. I feel it here.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: He was here, ſir, but he is gone, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: So, ſo, he's loſt. He muſt be cried, or we ſhall never finde him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le warrant you, I'le find him yet to night, ſir. Pray Gentlemen pay you the Reckoning, I'le wait upon my father home.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Was that ſpoke like a ſon of mine? muſt o|thers pay your reckoning, and I in place; take that, and do not make me mad. And why ſhould you home with me? I pray, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Becauſe ſir, it grows dark, and 'tis the worſt way as it is about the town; ſo many odde holes a man may ſlip into; pray take me with you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Pray take no care for me, ſir, and let the way be as it is. Do not think me worſe at it in the dark then your ſelf, I beſeech you. But you talk't of the Reckoning, pray let not the want of money for that hinder the ſearch of your brother. There's towards your paines for that; and ſo for a farewel to you and your friends here, till I hear thou keepeſt better company, let me hear no more of thee.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: There was no way to get this money, and be rid of him, but to offer him my ſervice He would have driven me out before him elſe. But come, let's ſee my brother that went to ſleep in ſo warlike a Paſſion. I hope he'll wake in a better.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Mun Clotpoll, thou art dull.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: No, I proteſt, but ſtruck with admiration at the old Blades humour.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Come, Dammy and the reſt, be merry. I vow, we'll ſup together, and ſo at laſt hear all thy diſ|mal ſtory.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: I mean he ſhall, and ſuch an Audit make,
As ſhall reſtore her honour from the ſtake.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p:
WHat has this Coxſcombe Cockbrayne writ me here? That he deſires his ab|ſence be excuſ'd. What have I to do with him? when I ſend for him, let him come to me. That he is up|on a point of diſcovery in a moſt excellent project for the weeding of this Garden? what Garden? what project? A project he ſays here for the good of the Republike, Repudding. This fellow has in ſtead of braines, a Cob-web in his Noddle, with little ſtrawes, feathers, and wings of dead Butterflies hanging in it, that having motion by his aery fancie, there dance and keep a Racket; 'tis to teach women ſilence, or ſome ſuch fooliſh impoſſibility. He is ambitious to be call'd into authority by notice taken of ſome ſpe|cial ſervice he is able to do the tate aforehand. But what great ſervice he is able to do it, or which way to undertake it, falls not in the reach of my imaginati|on. But good Mr. Croſwill, by your favour now, what reaſon have you to ſlight or wrangle at this man? this honeſt Cockbrayne? that has alwayes been a con|ſtant friend to you, and officious in many good wayes, and is a Gentleman, not only of good deſcent and e|ſtate, but of a good diſpoſition. And you two, Mr. Croſſewill, by your leave, have alwayes agreed like
neighbours children. I, the divel was in't, and now he vexes me again; we agreed in one point ſo well, that we have undone a couple of our children by it, and hindred the getting of I know not how many more. His ſon and my daughter ſhould have married. And on a ſndden he and I both conſented to a diſlike of the match and broke it, and have both repented it an hundred times ſince. We agree very wel in that point; and now is his ſon irrecoverably loſt, and my daughter reſolutely bent to be an Ape-leader in Limbo. But whats all this to the affliction I ſuffer in my ſons now? that one of them from a riotous boy. ſhould grow into a Puritanical Woodcock; and the tother from a civil well-qualified fellow, turn'd abſolute Ruffian. There, there, I there's the devil in't. I could beat my ſelfe for getting ſuch children.
See, ſee, my Maſter for want of other company fal|len out with himſelf, and it pleaſe you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: It does not pleaſe me, nor thou pleaſeſt me, nor any thing pleaſes me. The world's bent to croſſe me, and thou ſhalt feel it.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O good ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Is it not ſo, ſir, was not that dunce Gabriel, a moſt notorious wilde thing

Before he ſteer'd a Religious courſe? but then he run ſo full a ſaile, that he paſſ'd and was beyond the line of Religion before he was aware; and as he paſſed it un|der the torrid Zone of Zeale, the Calenture took him o'the pate, that he is mad with it, and as far beyond Religion now as it is to it.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Sir, there's hope that he may he fetch't halfe way back again, by your fatherly advicement, and be|come a ſound man.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: And then was not Mihil ſo civil, that he made me even ſick to ſee him. And now is he flowen out as far into rior t'other way.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: But he, ſir, will appear a preſent comfort to you, he is reclaim'd already; you ſhall never ſee ſuch a Reformation in a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What's this you tell me? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: He has caſt off his long-curl'd haire and all.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.l: He had been better have cut his head off.
Where is he!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Below ſir, and a Gentlewoman with him, but very much afraid to appear to you. I never ſaw a man ſo timourſome.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Do you think it fit I ſhould go down to him, or he come up to me, fir, ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I'le fetch him, here's a life!

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: I charg'd he ſhould not come at this houſe too, for feare he might be catch'd with this mecha|nick fellows daughter, though her portion be around one. And let him take heed he look not at her.
Bleſſe me! what changeling is this? he's in his Brothers cut.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Sir,—Sir.—

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Would you ſpeak with any here, ſir, do you know me. I know not you, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: The ſenſe of your late diſpleaſure, ſir, has ſo humbled me into the knowledge of my ſelf, that on the wings of true obedience, I flew after you to make a childes ſubmiſſion at your feet, to crave your pardon for my riotous tranſgreſſion, and to ask your bleſ|ſing.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
A delicate ſpeech, pray take it for faſhion-ſake.
But if I know how to look towards thee.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray ſir, beſtow it really upon me.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: God bleſſe thee, I ſay, and ſo much many honeſt men beſtow daily on ſons that are none of their own, if thou beeſt mine, how cameſt thou thus like a fellow that had narrowly ſcap't the Pillorie, and brag'd in the publication of his eares? not an hair left to hide them.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: To ſhew my readineſſe to reform my life, ſir. And yet a willingneſſe withal to live, as well, as civilly, in which I am in all humility to preferre a ſuit to you. You know, ſir, I am but a younger bro|ther.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What will this come to?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Here is a widow, ſir, a Gentlewoman of great eſtate, and of a well-known life. Antient ſhe is, and has had husbands. How many?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Foure truly, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Foure ſir, I would not lie. Of which the worſt ſpoke well of her on's death-bed.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What's that to me or thee? come to the point.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I have all wo'd and wonne her, ſir, and crave but your good-will to marry her. I have brought a Church-man and a Kinſman to give her.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Why ſo, what needs two words then? do you think I can deny you?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: If he does grant it, 'tis the firſt requeſt that e're he granted in his life. Sure the old Match-ma|ker the devil thinks I am in earneſt to marry this beaſt. And puts a readineſſe in his hand to for|ward it.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Widow, you are welcome. Why call you not your Prieſt? or tarry ſir, let me queſtion you but a little, Do you think ſeriouſly you love this wi|dow?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Better then many men love their wives, I am perſwaded.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, what children have you wi|dow?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Never had any, Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Very well ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nor ever like to have any, fir, thats the com|fort. We ſhall live at the leſſe charge.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Thou art a covetous and a prepoſterous Knave. Wouldeſt thou bury up thy youth in barren ground? doeſt ſeek after wealth, and not after iſſue? doeſt love to feed on other mens leavings? or travel only in a beaten path? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: A man goes certaineſt on his journey ſo, ſir, and leſſe trouble it is you know to go in at a great gate, then a narrow wicket.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: You have ſaid enough, ſir, and delight to croſſe me; but I'le croſſe you for once, and lay a croſſe upon you, ſhall perhaps carry you to your grave. Go, fetch your Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le face it as far as I dare. I hope I ſhall have the grace to pull my hand from the book when it comes ſo far.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Widow, you are reſolv'd to have him too.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Before all men i'th' world by your fair leave, 1.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: You ſhall not have him.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Without your free conſent, I will not.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: I am reſolv'd I'le do't. And 'twill be the beſt croſſe trick that e're I did in my life. Pray let me ſpeak in ſome more private wirh you.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: If I but 'ſcape Bridewell, I care not.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
Now Tonie, ſhe's thine own, Now Siſter Kate;
he's thine. The Prieſt has pronounc't it. I ſay, A|men to't. And heaven give you joy.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now you have done the beſt brotherly office that ever made a Siſter happy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And the friendlieſt to a friend. We have been caſting for it, Sweet, this Twelve-moneth, and Heaven pardon me. I vow'd never to take acquaint|ance of my Father, till 'twere effected. Although I know of late he has been willing.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And ſo is mine, I know, but yet he ſwore, that I ſhould match my ſelf before he knew't, or I ſhould never marry.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You'll finde him of another minde towards me, and force me into wedlock preſently.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: You have ta'ne the likelieſt courſe that could be. But what is your diſguiz'd woman, Bro|ther.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: What you ſhall never know, Siſter, I hope.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Come ſir, I have broken off the match with your widow; and ſhe's content to leave you as ſhe found you. And now take me this pretty, ſimpring, plump-lip't, ruddie-cheek't, white-neck't, long-fin|ger'd Virgin in hand, or I will ſwindge you, Sirrah, look to't. If you cannot live civilly with a young wife, you cannot but be mad with an old, I think. Be|ſides, ſhe's a friends daughter of mine, and prepar'd by her diſcreet father here to love you. Come, and kiſſe her, quickly, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I cannot do't for all the wealth in the world.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Kiſſe a Maid I never ſaw above twice in my life.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: He will have me think him a baſtard, do I what I can. Canſt thou ſee a Maid twice, and not kiſſe her?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, twenty times, ſir, and not kiſſe her, or if once, not above, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: But you ſhall kiſſe her above and below, ſir, and in every room o'th' houſe, ſir, before you part. Stand faire pretty one.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I know not how to do't.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: You were not beſt let me inſtruct you. I can be angry too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: His back ſide's towards me.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Turne your ſelf, Sirrah, or I'le turne you. Go to, bend your body a little and be hang'd. So, now come your way, and ſay after your little Sir John here, I Mihil take thee, Lucie, &c. As learning ſhall enable him to proceed without book.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Pray let'em do it in the next chamber, they are too baſhful afore us. There are witneſſes enough. Go all in, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Widow, will you give me leave to obey my father?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: With all my heart, and ſay Amen to the marriage.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: I think I ſhall have my will at laſt upon one of my rebellious off-ſpring.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: And now, pray give me leave ſir, to let you know how happy I do hold my ſelfe in this marriage. I did like this Son better then the other before. And now I like him better then I did at my former view of him, by ſome Reformation that I do obſerve in him. And I do not a little rejoyce in the honour I may have to call you brother.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p:
That very word brother out of his mouth, has turn'd my ſtomack. I muſt pull all in pieces again. And yet let me ſee theſe young bloods when they
are ſet on't; if they do not marry, they will do worſe. Let em e'ne go on now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: You may eaſily conceive, ſir, what a com|fort it will be unto me, that I now growing old, and having (I give praiſe for't,) wealth enough, and no childe that I make account of but this one daughter, may, before I die, ſee Grandchildren that I may have by her ſufficiently provided for, be they more or leſſe in number, they may have enough.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: There he is again, he calls my Grand-chil|dren that ſhall be, his Grand-children. Am I a Gentleman, and can hear this? if it be not too late, I'le ſpoile the getting of your Grand-children.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Heaven give you joy. Heaven give you joy.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: What, are you married?

sp.speaker: Parſ.
sp.p: I do pronounce them man and wife.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Mad. Kat. And we are witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Croſſe.
sp.p: What remedy?

sp.speaker: Mih. Luc.
sp.p: We are, and crave your bleſſings.

sp.speaker: Croſſ. Rook.
sp.p: All bleſſings be upon you, (all ſa|lute).

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: But you, ſir, Mr. Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le only gratifie the Miniſter.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Do ſo, and pay him well, it is, perhaps, for the deareſt fault that e're thou didſt.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: There's for your paines, ſir. Madge, there's for you. Enough to purchaſe thee a Licence to ſell Ale, Tobaccho, and Strong-water again in Godpiece-Rowe, for here will be no dwelling for thee, I ſee that.

Now, brother Anthonie, go you all back to the com|pany we left, and ſee that my Inſtructions be followed
concerning my brother Gabriel, Nick, and his Dam|mie,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All, all.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Shall he go from me?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, but you ſhall follow him preſently, truſt to me Siſter. Go, take no leave of 'em. I'le bring 'em upon you preſently.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Are you at leiſure now, ſir, to tell me of your brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, to my grief, ſir, praying you may have patience.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: To your grief, ſir, he is not dead then? Younger brothers ſeldome grieve for their Elders death.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray bear it as you may, ſir I left him in an heavy plight. And let me ſpeak it with ſorrow, he lay ſpeechleſſe.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Alack-a day, good Gentleman, my ſon in-law, perhaps, is heire already.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: And haſt thou been here all this while fooling or wiving (all's a matter) & left thy brother in danger? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He's well attended, ſir, and look't unto. Nor would I wiſh you ſee his weak eſtate.
It can but grieve you, ſir, my wife and ſiſter, toge|ther with my ſelf, will go. Or if
It pleaſe my father Rooksbill here, becauſe his power in this quarter is available.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Co, ſhew the way. I'le go in perſon, I. My ſon's my ſon.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Nay, pray ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Yes, 'cauſe you have a wife, you ſhall con|troul me. Will you go on, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well, I'le bring you to him, ſir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What was your widow, ſir, ſhe ſtunk of Aqua|vitae, fearfully.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le tell thee as we go. Kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: What a drunken ſot was I, that knew thee not all this while? I vow, thy ſtory pities me. I'le marry thee, and turne thee to thy friends, for I am ſure I have none that will keep thee for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: I ask no further ſatisfaction of you, then to be honeſted by marriage. I'le work for a poor li|ving.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Prithee Mun ſeek me a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I have no acquaintance in their function, I.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: My Couſin Mihil ſaid he would bring or ſend one.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: There's no ſtarting, that Mihil has a fiſt o|ver me. I vow, and thou wert not his Kinſwoman, thou ſhould to the Common yet.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Father, how come you hither?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Did not the company ſend for me?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, not we.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The City-mouth, that peck't us at my lodging laſt night, came to me with an abominable ſcratch't face, and warn'd me on a buſineſſe hither.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I ſmell ſome trick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Some treacherie upon the brotherhood, per|haps.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Timorous thing! what in our own Quar|ter?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: If you doubt any thing, 'tis beſt remove.
The fellow was ſorely handled.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I would but ſee the carcaſs of authority prance in our Quarter, and we not cut his legs off. Wel|come Tonie, what haſt thou brought the word here to paſſe for the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, you muſt make a wedding-night on't Nick, Mihil will go no leſſe.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: My Vow is paſſ'd, and before you, ſir, I con|firm it. This is my wife. Anon, you ſhall perform the holy Ceremony,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis well, pray ſir, retire your ſelf to the next room there a while, and ſtay you with him, Lady.
But what do you with Gabriel? Is it not time to wake him yet?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: 'Tis now upon the point, h'as ſlept two houres.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Father, you'll ſee a brave experiment upon a Gentleman that has been a youth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And of the Philoblathici, as we are now.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And ſince was grown one of the reformed, and we are now in practice to retrive, and bring him back to his firſt condition.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Have you followed all Mihils directions?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Hitherto we have. Firſt, you ſaw he was laid defunct in Sack, next in his ſleep, we have accou|tred him in martial ab liments, and now we mean to wake him with alarmes ſhall affright the ſilly humour out of him, and render him his warlike faculty, or our Art failes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where be the Wenches?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The Siſters of the Scabberd, there's the ſport on't. They have their parts to play upon him too. But for his drink now when he wakes, you ſaid you would have a bottle of the womans what do you call't yonder? the Medea.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What? the charm'd liquor that Medea brew'd to make old father Aeſon young again?
Muſt that renew his youthful ſpirit in him?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, Sack will do bette●. When he wakes he will be very dry, then a quart-draught of good Ca|narie will ſo ſcrew him up. 'Tis time 'twere now in practice. So, ſoftly, ſoftly. We muſt but halfe wake him at firſt.
sp.stage: A Bed put forth, Gabriel on it, Bettie and Frank.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O ſome ſmall drink.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Here, drink it off, ſir, (Drinks) D●um and Trumpet. An Alarm.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surpriz'd by th' enemie, whileſt we have plaid the Sluggard in our Tents.

sp.speaker: Capt. Nick. Clot.
sp.p: Hold Captain, hold, we are your ſouldiers.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Y'are Mutineers, and have diſturb'd my reſt. And I'le do Martial Juſtice on you all.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, hold, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Know you not diſcipline? or are you growen rebellious in the Camp. I'le teach you war|fare.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You have conjur'd a fury into him to beat us into fitters.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: My pate bleeds for't; I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I'le make you know command.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Noble Commander, hold thy furious hand, and heare thy ſouldiers ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What have we women for our Martial Mu|ſick?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: None but the She-Trumpet, a neighbour here, and her Siſter, that was Drum-ma●or to my Coun|trey-Amazons, that pull'd up the Incloſures to lie all in Common.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Is the enemy i'th' field?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Upon their march, Captain, and we your of|ficers: But rowſ'd you up to be in readineſſe.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
You are my Lieutenant, you my Ancient, and you two my Sergeants; and you muſt know the Com|mander
you ſerve under, to be none of thoſe Letter-carriers that know not ſo much as the termes of diſ|cipline, what a Flanker is, Nor a Raveling is. Nor a Petarre is. Nor a Curtain is. Nor a Bulwark is. Nor a Baſtile is. Nor a Counterſcarp is. Nor a Caſemate is. A Gabion is: Nor any left word of fortification. How can ſuch freſh-water Captains command?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Right noble Colonel. He ſhall be our Co|lonel.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: One ſouldier made up of Sack, is worth as many as would drink a freſh water river dry.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I knew, men of abilities ſhould at laſt be put in action.
sp.l: Valiant men and wiſe,
Are only fit for weighty enterpriſe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O noble Colonel.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What would an upſtart Militaſter now, That knew no rudiments of diſcipline, nor Art of warre, do in a ſudden ſervice? or ſay, when I know how to have my Ordnance planted here, my Cavalrie mount|ed here, my Battery-diſcove●er on ſuch a point, my Trenches cut thus, my Mine carried thus, my Gabi|ons raiſ'd thus. Here my Parapet, there my Palliſadoe o'th'top of that. The enemie made ſaltable ſix hun|dred paces there. And I draw out my Musketeers to flank 'em in their Trenches here, while my Pikes and Targeteers advance to the breach there. What would Captain, my Lords man, or Sergeant-major, my Ladies Kinſman, ſent in by honourable favour, do or ſay in ſuch an expedition?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Braver and braver ſtill.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: This goes beyond the Blade and the Bat|toon.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
Or how would their braines lie in their breeches, when the able Captain leads up his men in the Head of a Troop bravely, charges with his ſhot,
makes a ſtand with his Pikes, does execution with his Sword, the Cannon playing, the Drum beating, the Shot thumping, the Enſignes waving, the Armes claſhing, the Aire rending, Duſt and Smoke clouding, Blood raining. And then to bring up ſuch a Diviſion to fight, make good ſuch a Ground, relieve ſuch a Squadron, fetch off ſuch a loſſe, r'enforce the Ranks that are broken. March on, Come off. Beat the Beſſognes that lie hid in the Carriages. O the renown|ed life of a worthy Commander.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Sound Drum and Trumpet.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Colonel, a Colonel.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Whither haſt thou brought me? does thy brother lie ſpeechleſſe in this houſe? ha! what in the name of tumult can theſe be?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray ſit, attend, you will be pleaſed a|non.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: A ſtill march now. So, I have loſt a great ma|ny of my men. But courage yet, you poor remainder of my ſcatter'd Troops. Stand. Qni vala. An Am|buſcado of the enemy. Alarme. Lieutenant, charge in with your Shot. Now Gentlemen, for the honour of Covent-Garden, make a ſtand with your Pikes; in to the ſhort ſword; well fought, take Priſoners. Sound a Retreat now. Faire, faire i'th' coming off. So, 'twas bravely perform'd.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Muſt we not fall to rifling now, Colo|nel.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Part faire on all ſides, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What's this, a viſion, ſure I do aile ſome|thing.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Is't poſſible it is thou? art thou run mad as far as hell the tother way now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.l: My wicked, caitiffe, reprobate ſon is here too.
Pray let me flee, I am but a dead man elſe.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You ſhall receive no harm, ſir Lay by your Armes my Maſters. I bring none but friends.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I hou canſt not make that good, my father's there.

sp.speaker: Mih
sp.p: I'le make him friends with thee. Go and di patch within.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'le ſee it done, and take our new made Brides with us for witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Rook
sp.p: Has his ſhame yet taught him to ſhunne my ſight.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And ſhall returne him inſtantly your com|fort.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Unpoſſible, unpoſſible.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Attend the event.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: I rather thought I ſhould have found you, ſir, diſputing with the Paſtors, and the Elders; yet to ſay truth, this is the better madneſſe. What can this mean? how came he thus tranſlated? what Charmes, or what Inchantments are upon him?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: What Babel was a building in my braines?
But now it turnes, and I can recollect
The knowledge of a father, brother, Siſter.
And that a thouſand vain imaginations,
Like ſcatterings of light things upon the earth,
Ruſhes, looſe leaves, ſprigs, ſtraws, and duſt
Contracted by a whirlwinde, were blowen up,
And lodg'd in the rich Seat of Contemplation,
Uſurping there the room of vertuous thoughts.
Honour awake me from this Lethargie.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What can thoſe women that appear like furies be in this action?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: They were but uſ'd as properties to give new motion to his mortified condition.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
I know not what to ſay to any thing; there
is ſome Spell upon me too. My anger has forſook me. What are thoſe men that bear a countenance. As if they ſtood indifferently affected to Bedlam and Bride-well.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Meaning by us, ſir. If our ſight offend you,
Know we are men that dare forbear the place.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I ſon, let's go, our ſtay is dangerous.
They look like Peace-maintainers, we●ll fall off.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: O tarry, Gentlemen, we are all undone elſe. If you make not your peace before you ſtir, both you and I muſt ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: The Magiſtrates and Officers with their Bill-men have ta'ne us by ſurpriſe. They are i'th' houſe.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: O me! the blew Gown Colledge.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Wheels and whips. I feel what we muſt go to. Did not I ſay our ſtay was dangerous?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Did not I ſay there was ſome ſubtile pra|ctice upon the Philoblatici? and that we were betrayed hither?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: There's no eſcaping forth. And Gentlemen, It will but breed more ſcandal on my houſe, and the whole plantation here, if now you make rebellious up|roar. Yield your weapons, and welcome Juſtice but like ſubjects new, and peace will follow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: But where's Nick? where's Tonie?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: They ſhall yield up their weapons. So do you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes yes, 'tis beſt.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Shall we, ſir, ſhall we?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes ſir, you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p:
So, ſir, I will then, not the Blade alone. But
for your more ſecurity, the Battoon, There ſee my Armes forth coming.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Say they ſhall have faire welcom, What are they married?
sp.stage: Enter Nick. Dorcas, Ant. Kat. Luc.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, as faſt as troth and holy words can binde 'em.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.l: 'Tis well. Now ſir, let me entreat your favour.
'Tis my firſt ſuit to you ſince I was your ſon,
That before others entrances diſtract our troubled
Scoene, theſe may be reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Even unto the earth, ſir, and humbled with as true a penitence, as ſon can be for wronging of a father, I beg your pardon and bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Give it him, Brother Rooksbill, I dare ſay 'twill make him a good man.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Heaven make him ſo. My bleſſing and my prayers ſhall not be wanting.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What? my Neece Dorcas made an honeſt wo|man?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Was that the man that wrong'd my Couſin Dorcas?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, and has now made ample recompence.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Here they are altogether, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
Lay hands on all. Firſt, on that old Ruffian, the Incendiarie, that ſets the youthful bloods on fire here with his Infernal diſcipline. Next, take his ſons, there's one, that young Blade there, Have I now got within ye, Gentlemen? will you have Songs ex temporc? know ye me now? a ha! I'le be can'd the
Weeder of this Garden. Take up thoſe She weeds there. I have the rank one here. I took her ſtragling in my Round e'ne now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: My Tenant, I take it, Mrs. Margerie How|let.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Your widow ſir, I think.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: But for a ſhift ſir, now you know my aim.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: O good your worſhip, as you came of a wo|man.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Peace Circes, ceaſe thy charmes. What clu|ſter have we here now. O here's another of the ſons of noiſe.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: That's my ſon now, ſir, by your leave, and I'le baile him.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: What Mr. Rooksbil, are you here? what wo|man's this?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: My Neece, ſir, his ſons wife. And I'le baile her.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What Mr. Croſwill, you among this Ginge too?
How will you 'ſcape commitment?

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Cockbrayne? how his braines crow now?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Who's here? your daughters too? but what are theſe?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I hope they'l prove my ſons, and be indiffe|rent men in time, ſir, by that time their haire may grow, or be reduc't to an indifferent length.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: That's done on me already, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Now he looks as like a Rogue as e're he did again.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And ſir, for me, now that my Couſin is reſto|red, and the wilde fury of my wine abated.
I do you the obedience of a ſon, acknowledging my former formal habit was more of ſtubbornneſſe then true devotion. For which I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: There's more deceit under theſe half Foot|balls, then in whole Pudding-bags. Well boyes, be you indifferent ſons, neither too hot nor too cold. I have found a fault in myſelf, I confeſſe. I will re|form it, and be an indifferent father.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O here's the man I ſought, whom, I confeſs, I am half ſorry to commit with the reſt, becauſe I found him civiller.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hoping you will not ſtake that good opinion, I'le now come nearer to you. And ſince here is ſuch a convention of love and joy. I hope my offering of a ſons true duty may ſinde I dulgencie.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What? my ſon Antonie?

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: How? how? your ſon that ſhould have had my daughter? Come hither Kate, now if thou lov'ſt him, take him. Are you content, friend Cock|brayne.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O ſir, moſt happily.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Why run you not together?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is too late, or needleſſe now for me to marry her.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Is't come to that? and if I do not ſwindge him—.Are you too good, ſir, for my daugh|ter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I do not ſay ſo, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Huswife, do you like him?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: No more then he does me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Get you together, or I'le ſwaddle you both into one, you perverſe fooles.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sir, the truth is, we are married already.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo, indeed, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Heyday! who am I trow? how durſt you do it vvithout my conſent?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I had your conſent, ſir, you commanded me to take my choice in vvhom I pleaſ'd, before you vvould take notice.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I cannot abide this vvrangling. Give you joy.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Joy and my bleſſing on you. Why I knovv not vvhom to commit novv.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: You have done the Common-wealth a ſpecial piece of ſervice the vvhile vvith your State-braines. But let us make a night of this, I pray.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sir, the parties have given me ſatisfaction, and I am content they be releaſ'd.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: There's an honeſt fellovv novv, and looks like one that vvould be beaten every day for ready money. Go novv, vvhile ye are vvell, and be ſeen no more in this Precinct.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Never and't pleaſe your vvorſhips, never.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.l: 'Tvvas built for no ſuch vermine. Hence avvay.
And may the place be purg'd ſo every day.
'Tis no unvvorthy member may be found,
To peſter or to vilifie this ground.
That as it vvas intended, it may be
A Scoene for Vertue and Nobilitie.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: TIs not the Poets Art, nor all that we
By life of Action can preſent on't, ye
Can or ought make us to preſume a Play
Is good, 'tis you approve't. Which that you may
It cannot misbecome us, ſince our gaines
Come by your favour, more then all our paines.
Thus to ſubmit us unto your commands.
And humbly ask the favour at your hands.

div.head: Another.
div.l: 'Tis done. And now that Poets can divine,
Obſerve with what Nobility doth ſhine
Faire Covent-Garden. And as that improves,
May we finde like Improvement in your Loves.
